== Sports ==

Bern was the site of the 1954 Football (Soccer) World Cup Final, a huge upset for the Hungarian Golden Team, who were beaten 3–2 by West Germany. The football team BSC Young Boys is based in Bern at the Stade de Suisse Wankdorf, which also was one of the venues for the European football championship 2008 in which it hosted 3 matches.
FC Breitenrain Bern, founded in 1994, also play in Bern.SC Bern is the major ice hockey team of Bern which plays in the PostFinance Arena. They compete in the National League (NL), the highest league in Switzerland. The team has ranked highest in attendance for a European hockey team for more than a decade. The PostFinance Arena was the main host of the 2009 IIHF Ice Hockey World Championship, including the opening game and the final of the tournament.
The PostFinance Arena was also the host of the 2011 European Figure Skate Championships.
Bern Cardinals is the baseball and softball team of Bern, which plays at the Allmend
Bern Grizzlies is the American football club in Bern and plays at Athletics Arena Wankdorf.
Bern was a candidate to host the 2010 Winter Olympics, but withdrew its bid in September 2002 after a referendum was passed that showed that the bid was not supported by locals. Those games were eventually awarded to Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada.
RC Bern is the local rugby club (since 1972) and plays at the Allmend. The ladies team was founded in 1995.
The locality of Bremgartenwald was home to the Bremgarten Circuit, the Grand Prix motor racing course that at one time hosted the Swiss Grand Prix.
Bern Bears is an NGO Basketball Club since 2010 in city of Bern.The Swiss Grand Prix was held on the Circuit Bremgarten street track from 1950-1954, with MotoGP also running their Swiss motorcycle Grand Prix from 1949 to 1954. The circuit eventually fell into disrepair after Switzerland banned motorports after the 1955 Le Mans Disaster, but they made an amendment in 2015 to host electric racing, which is how the Swiss ePrix happened in 2019.


== Economy ==
As of  2010, Bern had an unemployment rate of 3.3%. As of 2008, there were 259 people employed in the primary economic sector and about 59 businesses involved in this sector. 16,413 people were employed in the secondary sector and there were 950 businesses in this sector. 135,973 people were employed in the tertiary sector, with 7,654 businesses in this sector.In 2008 the total number of full-time equivalent jobs was 125,037. The number of jobs in the primary sector was 203, of which 184 were in agriculture and 19 were in forestry or lumber production. The number of jobs in the secondary sector was 15,476 of which 7,650 or (49.4%) were in manufacturing, 51 or (0.3%) were in mining and 6,389 (41.3%) were in construction. The number of jobs in the tertiary sector was 109,358. In the tertiary sector; 11,396 or 10.4% were in wholesale or retail sales or the repair of motor vehicles, 10,293 or 9.4% were in the movement and storage of goods, 5,090 or 4.7% were in a hotel or restaurant, 7,302 or 6.7% were in the information industry, 8,437 or 7.7% were the insurance or financial industry, 10,660 or 9.7% were technical professionals or scientists, 5,338 or 4.9% were in education and 17,903 or 16.4% were in health care.In 2000, there were 94,367 workers who commuted into the municipality and 16,424 workers who commuted away. The municipality is a net importer of workers, with about 5.7 workers entering the municipality for every one leaving. Of the working population, 50.6% used public transport to get to work, and 20.6% used a private car.


== Education ==

The University of Bern, whose buildings are mainly located in the Länggasse quarter, is located in Bern, as well as the University of Applied Sciences (Fachhochschule) and several vocations schools.
In Bern, about 50,418 or (39.2%) of the population have completed non-mandatory upper secondary education, and 24,311 or (18.9%) have completed additional higher education (either university or a Fachhochschule). Of the 24,311 who completed tertiary schooling, 51.6% were Swiss men, 33.0% were Swiss women, 8.9% were non-Swiss men and 6.5% were non-Swiss women.The canton of Bern school system provides one year of non-obligatory kindergarten, followed by six years of primary school. This is followed by three years of obligatory lower secondary school where the pupils are separated according to ability and aptitude. Following the lower secondary pupils may attend additional schooling or they may enter an apprenticeship.During the 2009–10 school year, there were a total of 10,979 pupils attending classes in Bern. There were 89 kindergarten classes with a total of 1,641 pupils in the municipality. Of the kindergarten pupils, 32.4% were permanent or temporary residents of Switzerland (not citizens) and 40.2% have a different mother language than the classroom language. The municipality had 266 primary classes and 5,040 pupils. Of the primary pupils, 30.1% were permanent or temporary residents of Switzerland (not citizens) and 35.7% have a different mother language than the classroom language. During the same year, there were 151 lower secondary classes with a total of 2,581 pupils. There were 28.7% who were permanent or temporary residents of Switzerland (not citizens) and 32.7% have a different mother language than the classroom language.Bern is home to 8 libraries. These libraries include; the Schweiz. Nationalbibliothek/ Bibliothèque nationale suisse, the Universitätsbibliothek Bern, the Kornhausbibliotheken Bern, the BFH Wirtschaft und Verwaltung Bern, the BFH Gesundheit, the BFH Soziale Arbeit, the Hochschule der Künste Bern, Gestaltung und Kunst and the Hochschule der Künste Bern, Musikbibliothek. There was a combined total (as of 2008) of 10,308,336 books or other media in the libraries, and in the same year a total of 2,627,973 items were loaned out.As of 2000, there were 9,045 pupils in Bern who came from another municipality, while 1,185 residents attended schools outside the municipality.


== Transport ==

The public transport in and around Bern is operated by BERNMOBIL, which is integrated into the fare network libero with coordinated timetables, which in itself covers the area of canton of Bern and Solothurn. The fare network includes any mode of public transport, such as any kind of train (including the urban S-Bahn), PostAuto buses, trams, buses (either trolleybuses or motorized buses) and others. Fares are based on the number of zones crossed during a specified time and are independent of the mode of transport or the number of connections. The central part of Bern, excluding Bümpliz, Betlehem, Bottigen, Brünnen, and Riedbach in the west of the municipality, is part of the fare zone 100.
Bern's central railway station Bahnhof Bern) (formerly known as Hauptbahnhof Bern) is not only the central network nucleus of Bern, but also of the whole urban and inter-cantonal region. It connects the city to the urban, national and international railways network and is Switzerland's second most busy railway station (202,600 passengers per working day in 2014).
A funicular railway leads from the Marzili district to the Bundeshaus. The Marzilibahn funicular is, with a length of 106 m (348 ft), the second shortest public railway in Europe after the Zagreb funicular.
Several Aare bridges connect the old parts of the city with the newer districts outside of the peninsula.
Bern is well connected to other cities by several motorways (A1, A12, A6).
Bern is also served by Bern Airport, located outside the city near the town of Belp. The regional airport, colloquially called Bern-Belp or Belpmoos, is connected to several European cities. Additionally Zurich Airport, Geneva Airport and EuroAirport Basel Mulhouse Freiburg also serve as international gateways, all reachable within less than two hours by train or car from Bern.

Despite some trepidation about bears being kept in captivity, we were pleasantly surprised by the very large enclosure with a mix if habitats alongside the river where the three bears live. We visited twice and were lucky to see all three although for most of the time they

There is a lot of information on the history of bears in Bern, it is clear how the two are linked and why the bear is the symbol of Bern. This is different from other zoos in that the enclosures are built on slopes or are pits made of stone. Only saw one bear. It's a few
Great views of the city over the river Interesting bear facts The lift to The river bank is wonderful. Bears sleeping on our visit

After a walk through the old town, you will arrive at the Barenpark. Trying to look for the bears but they were no where in sight. After a while , we heard children shouting and we guessed they might have found the bears. Yes, they were sleeping under the tree. How adorable.

It is a nice, sunny place with cafes and restaurants, perfect for spending some time with children. However, the bears are caged in an area and probably stressed terribly by the noise and burning sun...

Must do when you are in Bern, children obviously love it as do adults alike. We were lucky enough to see the three bears wandering around, eating and drinking. I think its a better view down the bottom near the lake. The "Bear keeper" I dont know what else to call the man
Title says it al... Quite spacious and bears could find shelters but overall the location didn’t seem a great natural environment for these animals...

It was March at the end of the hibernation season and three bears came out to play. Lots to see as they wandered round their park by the river, scratched, rolled and sniffed. Very sweet. My favourite sight in Bern.

Bern's mascot is the bear, which you'll see on flags, buildings and fountains throughout the city. You can get a glimpse of the living mascots Ursina, Bjork and Finn from the view point at the end of the Nydeggbrucke bridge. Here they roam freely in an open air fenced hillside

Bears are the symbol of the city of Bern and a great attraction for tourists. These animals are kept in a nice area on the side of the river Aar. During summertime they also have a splash in the artificial pool beside the river. It's easy to spot them eating, swimming, or
A lovely vantage point to take in the breathtaking views of the old town. Especially on a sunny day, seems like you can see for miles.
Bears have made their home in Berne since 1857; in 2009 they moved into the new and spacious Bear Park.
Yes it is winter yet we still saw a bear!! I can not remember the name but it was awesome!! She came out and got some beautiful sun. It is a great place on the river

The quickest access from the heart of the city would be to take Tram #12 from the main train station directly and exit at Barenpark. There are several spacious areas and pins that the bears are on display with room to roam. Go down to the Barengraben and learn the history of
wonderful view! wished that we could have seen the bears but in winter the bears are sleeping. great to go after a snow as the view is beautiful.

After driving for a while and made the kids anxious to meet the bears, We parked the car to the side of the road and waited for the bears to come out When it suddenly hit me, I remembered it's winter and I would have to wait for long time for the bears to make up... It paid

The Bear is prominent in the insigna of Bern. But poor bears that live in Bern. 3 bears living on a spot and thousands of people are watching them. I’m sure that taken good care of the bears, but I do feel a bit uncomfortable when I see so many people staring at these animals.

My husband and I enjoyed strolling along the water looking for the bears. It’s a scenic and lovely sight. We actually spotted the bears on our way out of the park... as we turned and stopped at a little bridge .. there they were in an obscure corner of the park! Smart bears!

We stopped for lunch at the Old Tram Depot and afterwards stopped to watch the bears. It can get pretty crowded if all the bears are out. They can also be seen along the river and in the water if they are released into that pen. We were lucky enough to see them playing in
Walk down the road well past Einstein's house and you will see the beautiful emerald colour river and the big brown bears. We were lucky to see one of them enjoying a bath!
What can you say, great place to see three lovely bears in the middle of Bern. Do yourself a favour and have a beer or even better have something to eat in the restaurant behind the bears.

Taking bus No 12 from the train station or from the central street of old town you get off at ''Barenpark''. You will see a lift that takes you down to the river bank and the park. Not many bears to see, the most interesting thing is the incedible views of the river and the

The bear park was great- a must see. The bears seemed happy enough so it was a pleasure to watch them play and swim in the sun. It is right on the river and free to the public and offers great views across to the cathedral and other sites.
I found it quite uncommon to find in a city-center an area with live bears but that’s it! It was nice to see them running between different areas.

The bear is the "mascot" of Bern, so this little bear park right on the water is a cute place to visit while in Bern. It's also right on the water so it's a nice spot. Plus the beats are pretty close so you get to see them.

Bern has always been the city of bears, and formerly hosted their bears in a medieval hole in the ground. It was sad to see the bears trapped in the hole. The city has created a great outdoor area along the river with several layers, trees, open space and access to water. You

There isn't much to see, but I felt like I needed to see the bears if I was in Bern and they were easy to find. Historically, it's a great story to think bears have been there for as long as they have, so it was a fun, short stop on my walk up and down the Kramgrasse.

They're just there chilling, living their best life in the old town of Switzerland's Federal capital. They go to sleep over the Winter so if you catch a glimpse of them before hibernation, recognise your luck. I'm a close neighbour and overall they're pretty quiet, tidy and keep

Yep! We walked over to the Barenpark,and there really are real bears! Walking around and around. I guess their quarters are better than the old pits, but it still looked a little sad to me. But..Bears!!
Visited many times but was recently lucky enough to see the bears from very close. Definitely a must see if you happen to be in Bern. Also awesome for the kids.
Following the trail set out by Bern’s 11 trademark colorful and historic fountains, we found the Bern Bear in BarenPark [Bear Park] and then rested our feet in the cool Aare River

My friend had been to the bear pit years ago and thought we should see it during our morning in Bern. The bear were not in the pit. Then we saw them in the adjacent hilly park. I was expecting cute black bears. We saw brown bears instead. The are the same species as my Montana
It is truly a cool experience to see bears in the middle of the city. Really exciting and the bears gave us a show by play fighting and growling. I really hope they are being well taken care of!

This is a pretty sizable enclosure for the bears and they have plenty of room to walk around. It’s really cool to see big live bears in the middle of the city but you can’t help but feel sorry for the, being in captivity.

Free admission to see the old small bear pit that was scraped to allow for more space for the bears the city keeps on display. Easy to find. It’s also an easy walk from the city centre, or take the number 12 bus.
Just so cool to see this park in the city. A definite must see! A little walk down to the river provides a great view of the bears!

This is a small bear enclosure where you can see them from the top or from the river's edge. This park is at the foot of the hill that will lead you to the Rose garden. Its free and a good place to rest and relax and have an ice cream from Eiswerkstatt. Its also at a tram stop.

The bears are in a spacious enclosure and wander happily around. The best view is from the Nydeggbrucke. The enclosure gives them plenty of room and they seem very happy and content. Easy walking distance from the city centre and there is a trolley bus from outside the railway

It really isn’t out of the way to go see the bears. You can walk around the city and get there easily. I walked from my hotel by the train station, passing through the old town in the early evening around 5 PM. I saw one bear in a bush and another one was walking around. It
You've got to go see these bears. They're really big, and fun to watch playing and relaxing in their pools.

Fun park that is historical! The bears were very active when I was visiting - climbing on the rocks in their enclosure. Good for a short visit and a photo opportunity. This is located on the far end of the city center by the Aare River.

Was greatly surprised by the small size of the Bear Park. There were 3 bears on the day we visited and although the enclosure was easily accessible, it was somewhat of a disappointment to see these bears in such a small area. There was a nice view point from the upper area

This review is late but I just wanted to say how amazing the park was and to see the bears interact with each other and the public. It was raining really bad the day my husband and l visited the park.

We stopped in to see the bears as we walked into the old town of Bern from our parking spot. I must say that it really is unbearable....and the area around the sleeping quarters really is grizzly. You might even say that the bears were having a Kodiak moment. No, in all

I don't have a problem with zoos, because I know how much zoos contribute to knowledge and conservation. I'm harder pressed to argue in favour of the Bear Park, where the bears seem to be simply kept because of tradition. True, their enclosure is new adn spacious. Whether

I understand that Bern has a history with bears but, still, it is heartbreaking to see this three bears live in such a small place. I visited in July, and the heat was very high, I do not think it’s going to revert (climate change), so I would advice to transfer the bears to the
This is an ok thing to see if you have not seen bears before. They are in a small enclosed area. Being from the Seattle we are use to seeing bears in the mountains all the time.

We were a youth group of 6 teens and 4 adults. Visited the old bear pits, stopped at the very clean free bathrooms, then had our packed lunch on the shady bleacher style steps between the bear park and the river. There is a free funicular/elevator for people with mobility
This popular tourist attraction has bears in their riverside habitat. They are kept here because Bern is named after bears. So their namesake and history is tied to bears.

Another free activity in Bern. While it was a little sad to see the bears in an enclosure, they did have a reasonable amount of space with access to the river and some woodland. The bears themselves looked healthy, and the facilities nearby were of a good standard.

We first visited over 20 years ago and the improvements that have been made to the bears’ enclosure were great to see. We felt a bit sad first time we saw it but they now have so much space and we got to see them swimming too. Lovely place to wander around.

I do understand that the bear is the symbol for Bern, but I do not know whether its really nice for them to be limited to space in the middle of the city. I think they would be much happier in their natural habitat. Apart from that, I think the management has offered a lot of

This was done well. The park is a bit smaller than I had thought it would be, but the bears honestly seemed very comfortable and happy. The walkway had many details about the bears, their lives, habits, and personal details. If you don;t see a bear there, the view is very

I like bears. But not like this. These creatures deserve something better, something bigger, something more natural. This is only a little better than your local zoo. This bear pit is for the comfort of the tourists not the bears. Where’s P.E.T.A when you need them?

The bear is a symbol for Bern so it was great to see a lovely open enclosure for the 3 brown bears. You can watch them from the area above and so not disturb them. They were walking beside the river area, resting under the trees , playing etc. It was great to see them so

The bears got upgraded facilities a few years ago. They now have a great view, a bath and most importantly more space. The kids loved to see them. You get there by just following the main street (Marktgasse, later turns Kramgasse) and cross the Nydegg Bridge. In warm weather you
Neat to see the bears after which Bern is named. Also free. Smelt really bad, I felt really bad for the bears, would not go back.

Unlike most other conservatories that may not offer very ideal environment for the animals, the Bear Garden has one of the best I have ever seen across different continents. The 3 bears (think dad, mom and daughter) have a big slope with lots of trees facing the Aare River and

The inclined elevator closes very early. Some of our family were not able to go down to view the bear park from alongside the river as the elevator had just ended service for the day. The enclosure for the bears is a nice facility.

...but it really is just 3 bears in a zoo like atmosphere. But I can tell the city loves the idea and are proud so that’s fine! Great walk along the river and beautiful view of the city from this park.

What a lovely attraction and centrally placed. We saw the bears being allowed through to the feeding area on 2 occasions. The behaviour of the male bear knocking in the access door was rather worrying at first but he clearly knows when feeding time is. Often the bears disappear

We went to Bern to see the old streets , was surprised to find the Bears . We first saw the old bear pits and felt that were a stark reminder of how they treated the Bears . It was a surprise to see the new enclosure which included different levels trees and a section of the
Well, a bit frustrating going there and not seeing the bears, but I suppose we can't expect them to be always out and about.

As you may read from the guide, Bears are symbols of the city and were kept in the pit from the 16th century or something. Since the city life and wild animals do not come together, in 2009 they were relocated to the place near the bridge in a special "park" which is more like a

Since they upgraded from the old bear pit to this new enclosure, not much can be said a part of the fact that it is impressive and touching to see how much bernese people are attached to have the animals of their flag in their city !

I was expecting a proper park where you could walk around and see the bears. What this really is is a bear enclosure next to the river where you can see three bears from afar if you're lucky. If you want to see bears, go to a zoo.

Yes, bears are the city mascot and it’s interesting to be able to see a few (3 I think) lumbering around a city park doing bear things. In a way it’s kind of cool but I also question the limited amount of space these wild creatures have and whether it’s right to confine them for
The kids enjoyed watching the bears roaming around. It was a nice walk down to the river with picturesque views of the old town. We had a lovely dinner at the restaurant beside the park.
I saw some bears. They are looked like happy bears. The bears have a great view of the city from their habitat, which must make them extra happy.
This is a vast improvement on the old Barenpit where the bears were housed at least here they can stretch their legs, more for the bears than the visitor.

Enjoying the fairy tale vibe of this city and what do we find...Bears, of course! Loved it, we saw beautiful bears, just wanted to check them out for a few min. but its hard not to just watch and watch and watch. They are magnificent! The park is wonderful and fun, you should
We were fortunate the bears were out when we visited. After walking away to the Rose garden and came back, the bears had been let out to their "pasture" down by the river.

We looked high and then we looked low but couldn’t find any bears. There are large bushes for them to get out of the sun and the public eye. It was the middle of the day and rather hot, so they may have been sleeping. Wish I had been.

Its a nice walk down through he 'Old Town' of Bern to the Bear Park. The Bear park itself is an excellent facility for the care of the cities bears. On the day we visited it was warm and sunny so the three bears we saw were out and about in the pens and seemed to be very well

Had to go see the bears while in Bern and thought it was fun for about 5 minutes. Ended up watching them for about 30 minutes because of my wife. During the entire time one bear laid down in the grass and two others paced back and forth. I’m not sure what I expected but it was

The park is a fantastic piece of open space, that combines Bern’s tradition of bears with the public open space of the city, through this beautiful green park that runs parallel to the river, and opens up to a linear stepped bank. The natural topography of the land creates two

It's a beautiful location by the river. You can get a clear view from above, below and from the bridge. The bears looked happy and the park was very natural. The old bear put it still on display, the contrast is interesting. Worth a visit.
The Bear Pits are an interesting stop. Since 1513 bears have been at home in Bern. The spacious bear park is worth the walk. The history of bears with Bern, makes this a special place.

It was so unusual to see life bears in the city and they living on they own and they looking happy , and it was in the downtown! great place to come with kids. actually bear is an ancient symbol of the City

OMG a bear pit! In the centre of a city!!!! One not too miss. Once you're there enjoy the fantastic views across the aare and over the city from the top terrace. Then take the stairs or lift down the bank to watch the bears frolicking in the water. Fantastic.
The bear place is a cute place to watch bears in Bern city !. Never seen anything like this before. Its also a great place to take a walk around the river.

When I was here in 1979, I thought there was something wrong about the bear pits. It didn't look like the bears belonged here. It wasn't natural. The current bear park is a huge upgrade. The bears have a LOT of room to roam and play and act like bears. If you're in Bern,
The bears have a large very natural habitat along the Aare river. We saw bears on the top of the habitat and then took funicular down to river where we saw the, in the lower habitat. Great for kids
This barenpark is a place you should visit if you visiting Bern. However winter/autumn isn't a good time as the bears were in hibernation. I went in january and it was a bit disapointing.
Seemed like the saddest bears around. Especially in the pit. Couldn't find any others in the larger enclosure.

Bern is supposed to have been named after the bears (one of the versions of the origin of its name). So a bear is the mascot of the city. I think it is really a good idea to actually keep bears in the city to show this connection. I would not approve if the animals were in a

If you visit the City of Bern, you must go see the bears at the bear park, which is across the river from the old city. It is easy walking or take the #12 bus. The habitat is large, so you have to be patient to see the bears. A good photo-op.
Three bears in the keep, and there is no entrance fee. Bring your zoom lens if you want to capture really good pictures of the bears.

Intrigued by this, I learned a bit more. The Bear has been a symbol of the city of Bern for a long time. In the 12th century, a Duke went hunting in a nearby forest and decided to name his new city after the first animal he met on his hunting expedition. The party came across a
Fun place to visit and watch the bears. They were moving around quite a bit compared to most zoos. They were fun to watch and you are close enough to get great pictures.

The bears have a large area, they are in the bear pit in the morning and go to the area near the river in the afternoon. If you compare the size of this of this 'cage' compared to the ones I have often seen in zoos, this is the biggest living area for bears I have seen. The

This is my city and i never get tired of coming here. You have a great view of the aare and just beside it is a restaurant where you can enjoy the view. Parking is around the corner. Not free though. But once you grab a beer in tramdepot walk down near the water and just enjoy
This is a small park, in my opinion. Worth a quick visit just for a walk and to look at the bears. Nice view to the river.

This park is situated in the Dählhölzli Tierpark and in a nice looking,well maintained habitat for bears. We saw two of the bears during our visit. It was spectacular to observe them from behind a glass wall in their pool while they were swimming and playing together. A must see

I went to the Barenpark during a visit to Bern, when we first arrived the bears were in the small enclosure being fed. When I returned they were in the larger enclosure, there are three bears. The bears are only out between April and October, otherwise they remain in their den.

My husband loves bears, we were very excited to visit and were not disappointed. A lovely spot to watch the bears roam around, eat and swim! The bears seem happy and have a nice amount of room to move around compared to most zoo enclosures. You can view the bears from the top,
This is the symbol of Bern and is obviously worth a visit. See the bears as close up as you would want to.

After seeing old Bern, with beautiful facades of buildings, nice wells and towers, and cross the bridge with an amazing view, what else can you wish but seeing some really bears playing. They have a nice landscape near the river, with shelters where they can hide, but there are
Two beautiful bears in the center of Bern. The attraction is very followed. You can see bears from many locations
This is where the city gets its name, fabulous pens with the bears enjoying their days wandering in their enclosures close to the river. well worth a visit.
really nice: one can enjoy nature, view, sun, water and land. and yet so near to the busy center. the walk by the river is great and offers banks all along to sit and rest and enjoy
Bears are not out much this time of year. You will see them a lot in april. Weather will be nicer and will make for nlgreat photos.

It was winter so I couldn’t see the bears but it’s a great place to walk. I had a black vanilla ice cream that I didn’t know it excited but it was great I’ll post a photo so yo can see. They also have a restaurant and bar with lots of options and the food was great. They also
I visited during winter so I suppose the bears are in deep sleep, but can't wait to visit during spring to see them. For now, the statue must suffice.

Bears live in Switzeralnds Capital since centuries. The new Bear Pit is more zoo -alike than the pit before and complies much better with animal protection requirements. Bern is maybe the only capital city in the world that tributes in such a way to its coat of arms...
Unforgettable place to meet bear for real. The park is pretty big for them. Absolutely free for visitors and right across the bridge. 20 min walk from the central train station.

I was pleasantly surprised to find that there are real bears here! I was expecting an old bear pit and sad stories about dancing bears in the 19th century. However, what I discovered was a large, modern space for three, very healthy and happy bears to live. I ended up spending

Bern was founded in the late 12century and the first animal caught on the ruling duke’s hunt was a bear so the city was named Bern and the black bear became the symbol of the new city. The first record of bears being kept in the city is from 1513. The bear park dates from 2009.
The bears are super lovely. The park is perfectly matched with city and nature. There's a lift in the park. Elderly and handicapped can also enjoy the park easily.

We're not enamored with zoos - mammals cooped up in smaller than natural areas. Given that, these bears have more room than in most zoos and even have access to the river. The views from the Nydeggasse bridge are impressive. You can walk down to the river, to see the bears up

We’ve heard that bear enclosure has been expanded and went to visit the bears. It was a very sad experience. Indeed, there is more space available to the animals now but it does not change the fact that they are caged and look extremely unhappy. When we visited the bears

The Bern bears were always a treat to see. Overall the space was quite large for the bears to roam and we enjoyed stopping by and seeing them on multiple days. They were often quite active and my daughter loved watching them.

The bears were active even on the super hot day we were there. One bear took a swim in their little pool attached to the river. It was fun watching the bears roaming around their compound, surrounded by the beautiful, ancient walls of the city.

I had to visit a couple of times to se the bears , they were either asleep in the wild bit or in the feeding area . Patience pays off and if you are lucky you will see the bears at play. Interesting to find out how bears are linked to Bern. Out of interest there is a bernese

It takes some luck to get a good view of the bears, either in the original bear pit or in the expanded habitat along the river. Even with that, it's well worth walking to for the great views of the old town looking back across the river. There's also a handy elevator to get

We were just walking through the city and found this park. Its interesting how much historic this town is and how bears are part of it. This park has 4 bears in it and a nice park view with the town in the background.

Interesting to learn how bears were part of the history of Bern.  The new enclosure is obviously much more natural than the old bear pits/cages, but still found it a bit weird to have bears locked up in the city centre.    Didn’t see any bears this time around because of the

Visited here on the advice of two locals. The bears are stunning creatures and seem to be very well cared for in a reasonably large area. It is very popular and you do get some great views but you are looking at wild animals that are in a pit!! Not sure about these kinds of

We found the fact that there were real live bears living naturally in a large city fascinating. The very large enclosure was an excellent home for the family of bears,who seemed to be healthy and content. The public could get very close to the bears. Know there has been

Was a bit worried to hear there were bears in the city, thought the enclosure would be small but it's bigger than they would probably get in any zoo and it looks well laid out. The bears are beautiful and look very healthy. There is a shop, restaurant lots of information points
You can see bears swimming and eating and playing from about 5m away! It's free, easy to get to, and right below the loveliest bar in Bern. What more do you want?!?!
This is something you must see while in Bern. There were 3 awfully cute big 🐻 🐻 🐻Bears! And,it was dinner time so they were all really really hungry!
Nice place to enjoy a view on the city bears. The park is ok, but the location is amazing, right next to the river and below a nice restaurant which brews its own beers!

I wasn't sure about keeping bears even though it is historic. Whilst they can't run free they do have a large area on the river bank to explore, have shade and water to cool off in. The park gives all their names and details and all around there are interesting facts about them.
Cute bears but only two of them in a small area. It's kind of a 'must-do' since there's not much to do in Bern but it was very underwhelming.

I came to this place from the park nearby, and first of all noticed people sat on the bank and refreshing their feet in the river. I did the same, envying people from Bern taking a bath in the water of the river running fast. Then I didn't stop at the zoo, but I surely recommend

In a kindly habitat, the bears are emblematic of the city of Bern. Stand on the bridge overlooking Old Town and the Bear Park.

Very cute!! No price to pay so donations are recommended. The bears are very visible for the majority of the enclosure and a lift will take you from the top to the bottom to view the bears from a different angle. We did wonder if the enclosure is slightly small but I believe

Interesting to see a mini-zoo exhibit on the hillside of a city, but unique to Bern. Read up on the history of why there are bears and enjoy checking them out from a variety of angles both on the same side of the river and opposing it.

The enclosure for bears is well designed with lots of space, trees and pond. However, we spotted only 3 bears who didn't seem to be enjoying their artificial habitat. As a foreign tourist, I had expected a larger bear family. The bear statues have not been maintained at
Nice place for a sunny afternoon, after seeing tge bears the Nearby Restaurant "altes Tramdepot" invites for a beer of its own brand and a meal.

This attraction is free. It is in easy walking distance of the city and we spent hours watching and naming the bears! This is the only tourist attraction in bern, yet amazingly quiet. Sit back. Relax. And enjoy bears swim 1m away from you!!

This is a quick, easy side trip from anywhere in Bern. While I guess it is a must-see, it isn't because of the exciting nature of the Barenpark, but more because of what the bears mean to the people of Bern. The bears are cool to see, and their environment is very nicely set up,
A must-see in Bern, don't miss it. Spend some time on reading the detailed information on the signs.

It is always a joy to see the family just across the bridge from the historic centre of Bern. They look so docile you would think you could pop down and give them a hug. Perhaps not. They are in good condition and there is plenty of shade for them in the warm weather.

I was pleased to see the bears had plenty of room to live their lives but I was horrified at the old space where they had lived. Any animal lover would be horrified that the government have not filled in the old small bear pit. There are many good zoos around the world to see

For years the bear (Bern is derived from bear according to local lore) at het entrance to the old town near the river was the main tourist draw and he was living in a very dismall bear pit, unworthy of a modern countrie's attitude to animal welfare. A couple of years ago the

Basically if you are in Bern --you go see the bears while you are here. Easy parking but lots of tourists busses parked everywhere. Simply we saw 3 bears living in a protected habitat on a hill next to a beautiful river. Very scenic area. I can't imagine driving miles out of

Most fun is if you can find the 3 bears and follow their actions for a while. They're not in the pits anymore, but there's an informative display in one of the original pits. Walk there from the downtown, or take the tram.

I would rate this a 5 but in theory I have an issue about caged animals and being in a "run" effectively in the middle of a city, easily seen had me conflicted as I felt so sorry for them. However, given the area used to have bears everywhere and now the locals believe there

All the tourists seem to go over the bridge to this part of the town; there is a bus stop also. Bern means bear, apparently, and the crest of the canton has the bear figure on it. There is a bear fountain right near the clock tower. So, there is a bear park and right beside it

The bear park is at the end of the main street just over the bridge that runs through the old town. The bears seem to have a good environment to live and looked happy. It was a hot day and we saw a bear (Bjork?) lazing in the water and walking around looking for food. Also

They really give the bears a ton of beautiful space to roam around. They can even go in the water if they want. The three or them were hanging out very close to where we were standing at the railing which was great. They also had a viewing of them being fed which was cool.
The Barenpark has historic significance (the bear is on the Bern crest). Still, I cannot believe that the city does not display them in a more humane and dignified fashion.

A free and fun exhibit to find all of the bears on display. Bears roam freely in a beautiful environment, have a fishing area and appear to be very comfortable. A tram is available to those who wish to observe the bears from different levels. There is a beautiful walk along the

the poor bears i caged in this hill that looks like nature cage with much space, but does it make the situation better??!?!?! There are fences and the poor bears are caged no matter how space and food you give them. PLEASE FREE THEM!!!!
Great views. Excellent food. Something for all the family. Dads know what i mean. They brew their own beer here and it is yummy.

Since the bear is such an important symbol in Bern, it's really cool that they still have the bears here to see- you can look at their old cement enclosures behind- cool to see how far they have come. The exhibits are quite large and the bears were easy to see enjoying some deer

The bears used to be in the small bear pit and not closer to the river in a much bigger location with a much better habit . easy to watch , now nice to watch without thinking its a zoo

Nice attraction in Bern, conveniently located at the old city and easy to reach using city Tram. It was really nice to see the Bears at the natural surroundings. There should be several of them but we managed to see only one, which was out in the open. Area surrounding the bear

In the heart of Bern, just off the bridge, this is a real attraction. He bears roam free in their big enclosure. We've seen then in the water and running about in the trees, etc. Great views for everyone. No formality and totally free of charge.
Saw 3 of them. One was asleep & the other two were wrestling in the water. Was really interesting to see bears housed in a city. The enclosure is spacious and the bears look very well taken care of.
A must visit on your tour though Bern. Bears, right in the center of town! Very cool experience and a beautiful habitat for them
Of course they can't reach you :) . But at least you can see them not in a zoo, but in public and enjoy watching them taking bath.

situated across the river, out side and at the apex of the hair pin loop of bern city, there is a bear park. the name of the city is after the bears and they bears are very respected in switzerland. even on the roads and water fountains you can see lots of bears wearing army

it is a park in the heart of Bern... where three bears live in..... poor bears!!! I understand it is a touristic place, I understand the legend that brought them here but it is unvelieveble. Free these bears! who cares about the legend?

Every tourist in bern must have to see bear park. Located directly on the Aare, with a great restaurant in the river.

This was like a zoo for bears.This is probably the closest you will get.We made this our last stop and the fought the bus to train station

If in Bern don't miss it You can see bears in there habitat in the park take the angular lift down walk in the promenade enjoy the park Thou small it's a must see

text.wiki:
The Natural History Museum of Bern (German: Naturhistorisches Museum Bern) is a museum in Bern, Switzerland.  In its teaching and research it cooperates closely with the University of Bern.  It is visited by around 131,000 people yearly.


== History ==
The museum is owned by the Burgergemeinde of Bern, so it is also known as Naturhistorisches Museum der Burgergemeinde Bern.  It was officially founded in 1832.  It is located on Bernastrasse, in the Kirchenfeld quarter, in a building that was erected between 1932 and 1934, opened in 1936 and expanded several times since then.  Previously the exhibits were kept in a building on Hodlerstrasse built from 1878–81 and demolished in 1936; and earlier still, in the library gallery of a former college building. In 2016, the museum was visited by around 131,000 people.


== Collection ==
The museum is known for its set of over 220 life-sized dioramas, featuring preserved animals from Switzerland, Africa and Asia; it also owns a collection of minerals from the Alpine region, samples of gold discovered at various locations in Switzerland, meteorites, a large stock of invertebrates, and Switzerland's largest collection of animal skeletons and bones.


=== Mammal dioramas ===

The dioramas originate from a collection of big game animals from Africa, bagged by the London-based Bernese painter and game hunter Bernhard von Wattenwyl (together with his daughter Vivienne) during an expedition in 1923–24.  A total of 130 of these animals are on display, in 33 dioramas along two darkened corridors.  The dioramas are designed and furnished according to the animals' natural habitat.
There is a further section displaying native birds and mammals, with over 600 animals in 164 dioramas.  This section was previously on display in the Heimatmuseum, opened around the outbreak of World War II.
The upper basement contains five dioramas of Asian animals threatened with extinction: snow leopards, orangutans, giant pandas, Indian rhinoceroses, and tigers.
A fourth section called "Nordic Animals" features stuffed bears, muskoxen, seals, moose and birds, in nine dioramas containing 66 individual animals.
One of the museum's biggest attractions is the stuffed hide of Barry, the St. Bernard who is said to have saved the lives of over 40 people.  A special exhibit dedicated to him was held in 2001.


=== C'est la Vie ===
The museum's largest exhibit draws on the four million items to explore the biological and psychological facets of live. Visitors are invited to use sight, smell and sound to discover the world's tremendous biodiversity and its greater implications in human existence. Films, tactile and audio installations attempt to not only present scientific answers to these basic questions, but illustrate philosophy into the metaphysics of studying life.
The exhibit's first section repeats the phrase "There is no life without death." Part of the exhibition's definition of life is that all living things die, and through their decomposition stimulate more life. This section presents the life inside a pig carcass (paradisaically living off of the pig's demise), the oldest living animal (the Antarctic glass sponge) and the human fascination with death (featuring many art installations including H.R. Geiger's original mask for the film Alien.) The museum is, in essence, a repository for dead animals, and this section pays homage to their collectors and exhibits. Visitors look onto treasures through a transparent floor in somewhat of a meta-mission: the museum too was founded on a fascination with the death of the world around us.
The second section discusses gender and sexuality. Thus, the exhibit expands its definition to note that all living things must reproduce and pass along their traits. Avian mating displays show the advantages and disadvantages of this system: the decorated male bird may attract predators as well as an appreciative female and his elaborate plumage may make it hard to fly. Over in the corner, a life-sized blue whale head and an oversized sea turtle represent r/K selection theory. This cycle of risk and benefit hinders even human childbirth. Larger brains give humans a clear advantage, but complicate biophysical matters with an enlarged braincase. 
The "World in the Head" section looks at the senses, the brain and the idea of consciousness. A Gertrude Stein quote and small animatronic display illustrates the senses that humans do not have. A mirrored room metaphorically takes the visitor into an infinity and asks if vision requires an infinite amount of brain activity.


=== Die Grosse Knochenschau ===
The largest collection of animal skeletons and bones in Switzerland is displayed under the name "The Big Bone Show" (Die grosse Knochenschau).  This room exhibits over 300 skeletons, including those of a fin whale and an Asian elephant.  Eight of the larger skeletons sit upon a continually revolving carousel.  The display cabinets contain numerous further exhibits, including 518 individual bones.


=== Albert Heim Foundation ===
The Albert Heim Foundation for the promotion of cynological research is based at the museum, and possesses the world's largest collection of canine skulls.


== World Spider Catalog ==

In 2014 the Natural History Museum of Bern took over the World Spider Catalog, created in 2000 by Norman I. Platnick of the American Museum of Natural History, converting it to a relational database.

text.wiki:
The Gerechtigkeitsbrunnen (Fountain of Justice) is a 16th-century fountain in the Gerechtigkeitsgasse in the Old City of Bern, Switzerland. It is the only Bernese fountain to retain all original design elements, and is listed as a cultural heritage of national significance.Thanks to its namesake figure, Hans Gieng's famous statue of Lady Justice, the Gerechtigkeitsbrunnen surpasses all other Bernese fountains in artistic merit. The iconic figure was copied throughout Switzerland up until the middle of the 17th century. The statue is a copy of the original, which was largely destroyed by vandals in 1986.


== Fountain ==

The fountain consists of an octagonal main basin and two smaller spillover basins. The main basin, made out of unadorned limestone plates held together with an iron ring, bears the date of one of the renovations, MDCCCXLV. In the centre of the main basin, bronze tubes emerge from the central pedestal, which was replaced in 1949. Atop it stands a narrow, festooned stone pillar decorated by an acanthus frieze.


== Statue ==
The life-sized statue on the pillar is Iustitia, "Lady Justice", the personification of justice. She is portrayed standing in gracious counterpoise holding her traditional attributes—sword of justice in her right hand, a balance in her left hand and a blindfold over her eyes.  Her costume is fashioned in an antique manner, with sandaled feet, one knee bared, wearing a decorative golden suit of armour adorned with bas-relief arabesques over her blue robes.
At the feet of Justice, four smaller busts crowd the pedestal: a Pope, an Emperor, a Sultan and a Schultheiss, whose golden chain of office is believed to have originally borne the Bernese arms. All figures have closed their eyes as in submission. They represent the Four Earthly Powers, the four forms of government according to Renaissance humanism: theocracy (the Pope), monarchy (the Emperor), autocracy (the Sultan) and the republic (the Schultheiss).


=== Symbolism ===

The ensemble represents the supremacy of Justice over all Earthly authorities; a variant of the medieval pictorial formula of virtue defeating vice. The contemporary belief in the divine nature of Justice is made more apparent in a 1558 Bernese drawing for a stained-glass window by Hans Rudolf Manuel; there, a winged Justice strides over the heads of princes whose symbols of power are broken. Divine Justice was a frequent element of political discourse in Reformation-era Bern. In the view of the reformators, doing justice according to God's word was the highest duty of all authority, superseding feudal rights. Such arguments were used, among others, to justify Bern's conquest of Vaud in 1536 from the dukes of Savoy.While the sword and scales are traditional attributes of Iustitia, the Bernese statue's blindfold is a novelty; only later did it become a common element in personifications of Justice and a general symbol for the principle of equality before the law. The blindfold implies that justice ought to be done without respect to rank or standing; that a just verdict is arrived at through introspection rather than with a view to outward looks. Gieng's Iustitia is a symbol of republican justice, and was a forceful public reminder of the Bernese Republic's authority through law.


=== Influence ===

Gieng's Iustitia was greatly influential on fountain designers up until the middle of the 17th century. In Switzerland alone, eleven "fountains of Justice" remain, and several others have probably been destroyed. Direct copies exist in Solothurn (1561), Lausanne (1585), Boudry, Cudrefin and Neuchâtel; designs influenced by the Bernese statue are found in Aarau (1643), Biel, Burgdorf, Brugg, Zürich and Luzern.


== History ==
The fountain was constructed in 1543, essentially in its current state, to complement an older well at the Nydegg. Its current name is first recorded in 1687. Renovations are recorded in 1584, 1589, 1668 and 1687. The sword and balance were removed, allegedly by the invading French, in 1798 and disappeared for many years; they and the figures' other paraphernalia have frequently been replaced. The figure was repainted in 1890 by Christian Bühler and in 1925 by Victor Surbek. In 1949, parts of the pedestal were replaced.


=== Vandalism ===

After having stood in place for 443 years, the statue was torn down after midnight on 13 October 1986 by means of a rope and tackle. It was largely destroyed by the fall. The act was not claimed by anyone, but was generally attributed to the Groupe Bélier, a militant youth organisation advocating Jurassic separatism. At that time, the Béliers frequently engaged in acts of vandalism to express the Jurassian separatists' outrage over allegations of irregularities in the plebiscites of 1974–75 that caused the Bernese Jura to not join the canton of Jura; and over what was, according to the separatists, a cover-up of these irregularities by the Bernese and federal authorities.Only one person was ever implicated in the destruction of the statue. Pascal Hêche, a 29-year-old mechanic and Bélier, retracted his initial confession and pleaded not guilty to having participated in the attack. The Bernese courts sentenced him to 22 months' confinement and to the payment of CHF 200,000 in damages; the judgment was upheld by the Federal Supreme Court in 1991 and 1992.Since the attack, the damaged statue has been in the process of restoration at the city's historical museum. The statue in place since 1988 is a copy.


== References ==


== Bibliography ==
Caviezel, Zita; Herzog, Georges; Keller, Jürg A. (2006), Basel-Landschaft, Basel-Stadt, Bern, Solothurn, Kunstführer durch die Schweiz, 3 (1st ed.), Bern: Gesellschaft für Schweizerische Kunstgeschichte, p. 164, ISBN 3-906131-97-1
Gamboni, Dario (1997), The destruction of art: iconoclasm and vandalism since the French Revolution, Reaktion Books, ISBN 0-948462-94-9
Hofer, Paul (1952), Die Stadt Bern, Kunstdenkmäler des Kantons Bern, 1, Basel: Gesellschaft für Schweizerische Kunstgeschichte / Verlag Birkhäuser, pp. 314–321, ISBN 3-906131-13-0
Schneeberger, Ursula (2006), "Zuo beschirmen die gerechtikeÿtt, (...) un wer es allen fürsten leytt. Staat, Krieg und Moral im Programm der Berner Figurenbrunnen",  in Holenstein, André (ed.), Berns mächtige Zeit: Das 16. und 17. Jahrhundert neu entdeckt, Berner Zeiten, 3, 2006: Schulverlag blmv AG und Stämpfli Verlag AG, pp. 157–161, ISBN 3-292-00417-9, ISBN 3-7272-1276-4CS1 maint: location (link)


== External links ==

text.wiki:
Bern [bɛrn] (listen) (Alemannic German: Bärn [b̥æːrn]; French: Berne [bɛʁn] (listen); Italian: Berna [ˈbɛrna]; Romansh: Berna [ˈbɛrnɐ] (listen)) is the de facto capital of Switzerland, referred to by the Swiss as their "federal city", in German Bundesstadt, French ville fédérale, and Italian città federale. With a population of about 140,000 (as of 2019), Bern is the fifth-most populous city in Switzerland. The Bern agglomeration, which includes 36 municipalities, had a population of 406,900 in 2014. The metropolitan area had a population of 660,000 in 2000. Bern is also the capital of the canton of Bern, the second-most populous of Switzerland's cantons.
The official language in Bern is (the Swiss variety of Standard) German, but the most-spoken language is an Alemannic Swiss German dialect, Bernese German.
In 1983, the historic old town (in German: Altstadt) in the centre of Bern became a UNESCO World Heritage Site.


== Etymology ==

The etymology of the name "Bern" is uncertain. According to the local legend, based on folk etymology, Berchtold V, Duke of Zähringen, the founder of the city of Bern, vowed to name the city after the first animal he met on the hunt, and this turned out to be a bear. It has long been considered likely that the city was named after the Italian city of Verona, which at the time was known as Bern in Middle High German. As a result of the finding of the Bern zinc tablet in the 1980s, it is now more common to assume that the city was named after a pre-existing toponym of Celtic origin, possibly *berna "cleft". The bear was the heraldic animal of the seal and coat of arms of Bern from at least the 1220s. The earliest reference to the keeping of live bears in the Bärengraben dates to the 1440s.


== History ==


=== Early history ===

No archaeological evidence that indicates a settlement on the site of today′s city centre prior to the 12th century has been found so far. In antiquity, a Celtic oppidum stood on the Engehalbinsel (peninsula) north of Bern, fortified since the second century BC (late La Tène period), thought to be one of the 12 oppida of the Helvetii mentioned by Caesar. During the Roman era, a Gallo-Roman vicus was on the same site. The Bern zinc tablet has the name Brenodor ("dwelling of Breno"). In the Early Middle Ages, a settlement in Bümpliz, now a city district of Bern, was some 4 km (2 mi) from the medieval city.
The medieval city is a foundation of the Zähringer ruling family, which rose to power in Upper Burgundy in the 12th century. According to 14th-century historiography (Cronica de Berno, 1309), Bern was founded in 1191 by Berthold V, Duke of Zähringen.
In 1218, after Berthold died without an heir, Bern was made a free imperial city by the Goldene Handfeste of Holy Roman Emperor Frederick II.


=== Old Swiss Confederacy ===

In 1353, Bern joined the Swiss Confederacy, becoming one of the eight cantons of the formative period of 1353 to 1481.
Bern invaded and conquered Aargau in 1415 and Vaud in 1536, as well as other smaller territories, thereby becoming the largest city-state north of the Alps; by the 18th century, it comprised most of what is today the canton of Bern and the canton of Vaud.
The city grew out towards the west of the boundaries of the peninsula formed by the river Aare. The Zytglogge tower marked the western boundary of the city from 1191 until 1256, when the Käfigturm took over this role until 1345. It was, in turn, succeeded by the Christoffelturm (formerly located close to the site of the modern-day railway station) until 1622. During the time of the Thirty Years' War, two new fortifications – the so-called big and small Schanze (entrenchment) – were built to protect the whole area of the peninsula.
After a major blaze in 1405, the city's original wooden buildings were gradually replaced by half-timbered houses and subsequently the sandstone buildings which came to be characteristic for the Old Town. Despite the waves of pestilence that hit Europe in the 14th century, the city continued to grow, mainly due to immigration from the surrounding countryside.


=== Modern history ===
Bern was occupied by French troops in 1798 during the French Revolutionary Wars, when it was stripped of parts of its territories. It regained control of the Bernese Oberland in 1802, and following the Congress of Vienna of 1814, it newly acquired the Bernese Jura. At this time, it once again became the largest canton of the Confederacy as it stood during the Restoration and until the secession of the canton of Jura in 1979.
Bern was made the Federal City (seat of the Federal Assembly) within the new Swiss federal state in 1848.
A number of congresses of the socialist First and Second Internationals were held in Bern, particularly during World War I when Switzerland was neutral; see Bern International.
The city's population rose from about 5,000 in the 15th century to about 12,000 by 1800 and to above 60,000 by 1900, passing the 100,000 mark during the 1920s.
Population peaked during the 1960s at 165,000 and has since decreased slightly, to below 130,000 by 2000.
As of September 2017, the resident population stood at 142,349, of which 100,000 were Swiss citizens and 42,349 (31%) resident foreigners. A further estimated 350,000 people live in the immediate urban agglomeration.


== Geography and climate ==


=== Topography ===

Bern lies on the Swiss plateau in the canton of Bern, slightly west of the centre of Switzerland and 20 km (12 mi) north of the Bernese Alps. The countryside around Bern was formed by glaciers during the most recent ice age. The two mountains closest to Bern are Gurten with a height of 864 m (2,835 ft) and Bantiger with a height of 947 m (3,107 ft). The site of the old observatory in Bern is the point of origin of the CH1903 coordinate system at 46°57′08.66″N 7°26′22.50″E.
The city was originally built on a hilly peninsula surrounded by the river Aare, but outgrew natural boundaries by the 19th century. A number of bridges have been built to allow the city to expand beyond the Aare.
Bern is built on very uneven ground. An elevation difference of up to 60 metres exists between the inner city districts on the Aare (Matte, Marzili) and the higher ones (Kirchenfeld, Länggasse).
Bern has an area, as of 2009, of 51.62 km2 (19.93 sq mi). Of this area, 9.79 km2 (3.78 sq mi) or 19.0% is used for agricultural purposes, while 17.33 km2 (6.69 sq mi) or 33.6% is forested. Of the rest of the land, 23.25 km2 (8.98 sq mi) or 45.0% is settled (buildings or roads), 1.06 km2 (0.41 sq mi) or 2.1% is either rivers or lakes, and 0.16 km2 (0.062 sq mi) or 0.3% is unproductive land.Of the developed area of Bern, 3.6% consists of industrial buildings, 21.7% housing and other buildings, and 12.6% is devoted to transport infrastructure. Power and water infrastructure, as well as other special developed areas, made up 1.1% of the city, while another 6.0% consists of parks, green belts, and sports fields.
Of Bern's total land area, 32.8% is heavily forested. Of the agricultural land, 14.3% is used for growing crops and 4.0% is designated to be used as pasture. Local rivers and streams provide all the water in the municipality.


=== Climate ===
According to the Köppen Climate Classification, Bern has a humid continental climate (Dfb) closely bordering on an oceanic climate (Cfb).
The closest weather station near Bern is located in the municipality of Zollikofen, about 5 kilometres (3 mi) north of the city centre. The warmest month for Bern is July, with a daily mean temperature of 18.3 °C (64.9 °F), and a daily maximum temperature of 24.3 °C (75.7 °F). The highest temperature recorded at Bern / Zollikofen is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), recorded in August 2003. On average, a temperature of 25 °C (77 °F) or above is recorded 40.7 days per year, and 6 days per year with a temperature of 30 °C (86 °F) or above at Zollikofen, and the warmest day reaches an average of 32.1 °C (89.8 °F).There are 103.7 days of air frost, and 22.3 ice days per year at Bern (Zollikofen) for the period of 1981–2010, as well as 14.1 days of snowfall, 36.7 days of snow cover per year and the average amount of snow measured per year is 52.6 centimetres (20.7 in). On average, January is the coldest month, with a daily mean temperature of −0.4 °C (31.3 °F), and a daily minimum temperature of −3.6 °C (25.5 °F). The lowest temperature ever recorded at Bern (Zollikofen) was −23.0 °C (−9.4 °F), recorded in February 1929, and typically the coldest temperature of the year reaches an average of −12.8 °C (9.0 °F) for the period of 1981–2010.


== Politics ==


=== Subdivisions ===
The municipality is administratively subdivided into six districts (Stadtteile), each of which consists of several quarters (Quartiere).


=== Government ===

The Municipal Council (de: Gemeinderat, fr: conseil municipal) constitutes the executive government of the City of Bern and operates as a collegiate authority. It is composed of five councillors (German: Gemeinderat/-rätin, French: conseiller/conseillère municipal(e)), each presiding over a directorate (de: Direktion, fr: direction) comprising several departments and bureaus. The president of the executive department acts as mayor (de: Stadtpräsident, fr: Le Maire). In the mandate period 2017–2020 (Legislatur) the Municipal Council is presided by Stadtpräsident Alec von Graffenried. Departmental tasks, coordination measures and implementation of laws decreed by the City Council are carried by the Municipal Council. The regular election of the Municipal Council by any inhabitant valid to vote is held every four years. Any resident of Bern allowed to vote can be elected as a member of the Municipal Council. Contrary to most other municipalities, the executive government in Berne is selected by means of a system of Proporz. The mayor is elected as such as well by public election while the heads of the other directorates are assigned by the collegiate. The executive body holds its meetings in the Erlacherhof, built by architect Albrecht Stürler after 1747.As of 2017, Bern's Municipal Council is made up of two representatives of the SP (Social Democratic Party), and one each of CVP (Christian Democratic Party), GFL (Grüne Freie Liste a.k.a. Green Free List, who is the newly elected mayor since 2017), and GB (Green Alliance of Berne), giving the left parties a very strong majority of four out of five seats. The last regular election was held on 27 November 2016/15 January 2017.

Dr. Jürg Wichtermann is State Chronicler (Staatsschreiber) since 2008. He has been elected by the collegiate.


=== Parliament ===

The City Council (de: Stadtrat, fr: Conseil de ville) holds legislative power. It is made up of 80 members, with elections held every four years. The City Council decrees regulations and by-laws that are executed by the Municipal Council and the administration. The delegates are selected by means of a system of proportional representation.
The sessions of the City Council are public. Unlike members of the Municipal Council, members of the City Council are not politicians by profession, and they are paid a fee based on their attendance. Any resident of Bern allowed to vote can be elected as a member of the City Council. The parliament holds its meetings in the Stadthaus (Town Hall).The last regular election of the City Council was held on 27 November 2016 for the mandate period (German: Legislatur, French: la législature) from 2017 to 2020. Currently the City Council consist of 24 members of the Social Democratic Party (SP/PS) including 2 members of the junior party JUSO, 9 Green Alliance of Berne (GB), 9 The Liberals (FDP/PLR), 9 Swiss People's Party (SVP/UDC), 8 Grüne Freie Liste (GFL) (Green Free List), 8 Green Liberal Party (glp/pvl) including one member of its junior party jglp, 3 Conservative Democratic Party (BDP/PBD), 2 Christian Democratic People's Party (CVP/PDC), 2 Evangelical People's Party (EVP/PEV), 2 Junge Alternative (JA!) (or Young Alternatives), 2 Alternative Linke Bern (AL), 1 Grüne Partei Bern – Demokratische Alternative (GPB-DA) (or Green Party Bern – Democratic Alternative), and 1 Swiss Party of Labour (PdA).
The following parties combine their parliamentary power in parliamentary groups (German: Fraktion(en)): AL and GPB-DA and PdA (4), SP and JUSO (24), GB and JA! (11), GFL and EVP (10), glp und jglp (8), BDP and CVP (5), FDP (9), and SVP (9). This gives the left parties an absolute majority of 49 seats.


=== National elections ===


==== National Council ====
In the 2019 federal election for the Swiss National Council the most popular party was the PS which received 28.7% (-5.6) of the vote. The next five most popular parties were the Green Party (25.2%, +7.9), the pvl (13.5%, +4.1), the UDC (9.5%, -2.9), PLR (4.2%, -2.8), and the BDP/PBD (7.0%). In the federal election a total of 49,030 votes were cast, and the voter turnout was 56%.In the 2015 federal election for the Swiss National Council the most popular party was the PS which received 34.3% of the vote. The next five most popular parties were the Green Party (17.4%), the UDC (12.4%), and the FDP/PLR (9.9%), glp/pvl (9.4%), and the BDP/PBD (7.0%). In the federal election, a total of 48,556 voters were cast, and the voter turnout was 56.0%.


=== International relations ===


==== Twin and sister cities ====
The Municipal Council of the city of Bern decided against having twinned cities except for a temporary (during the UEFA Euro 2008) cooperation with the Austrian city Salzburg.


== Demographics ==


=== Population ===
Bern has a population (as of December 2018) of 133,883.. About 34% of the population are resident foreign nationals. Over the 10 years between 2000 and 2010, the population changed at a rate of 0.6%. Migration accounted for 1.3%, while births and deaths accounted for −2.1%.Most of the population (as of 2000) speaks German (104,465 or 81.2%) as their first language, Italian is the second most common (5,062 or 3.9%) and French is the third (4,671 or 3.6%). There are 171 people who speak Romansh.As of 2008, the population was 47.5% male and 52.5% female. The population was made up of 44,032 Swiss men (35.4% of the population) and 15,092 (12.1%) non-Swiss men. There were 51,531 Swiss women (41.4%) and 13,726 (11.0%) non-Swiss women. Of the population in the municipality, 39,008 or about 30.3% were born in Bern and lived there in 2000. There were 27,573 or 21.4% who were born in the same canton, while 25,818 or 20.1% were born somewhere else in Switzerland, and 27,812 or 21.6% were born outside of Switzerland.

As of 2000, children and teenagers (0–19 years old) make up 15.1% of the population, while adults (20–64 years old) make up 65% and seniors (over 64 years old) make up 19.9%.As of 2000, there were 59,948 people who were single and never married in the municipality. There were 49,873 married individuals, 9,345 widows or widowers and 9,468 individuals who are divorced.

As of 2000, there were 67,115 private households in the municipality, and an average of 1.8 persons per household. There were 34,981 households that consist of only one person and 1,592 households with five or more people. In 2000, a total of 65,538 apartments (90.6% of the total) were permanently occupied, while 5,352 apartments (7.4%) were seasonally occupied and 1,444 apartments (2.0%) were empty. As of 2009, the construction rate of new housing units was 1.2 new units per 1000 residents.As of 2003 the average price to rent an average apartment in Bern was 1108.92 Swiss francs (CHF) per month (US$890, £500, €710 approx. exchange rate from 2003). The average rate for a one-room apartment was 619.82 CHF (US$500, £280, €400), a two-room apartment was about 879.36 CHF (US$700, £400, €560), a three-room apartment was about 1040.54 CHF (US$830, £470, €670) and a six or more room apartment cost an average of 2094.80 CHF (US$1680, £940, €1340). The average apartment price in Bern was 99.4% of the national average of 1116 CHF. The vacancy rate for the municipality, in 2010, was 0.45%.

=== Religion ===
From the 2000 census, 60,455 or 47.0% belonged to the Swiss Reformed Church, while 31,510 or 24.5% were Roman Catholic. Of the rest of the population, there were 1,874 members of an Orthodox church (or about 1.46% of the population), there were 229 persons (or about 0.18% of the population) who belonged to the Christian Catholic Church, and there were 5,531 persons (or about 4.30% of the population) who belonged to another Christian church. There were 324 persons (or about 0.25% of the population) who were Jewish, and 4,907 (or about 3.81% of the population) who were Muslim. There were 629 persons who were Buddhist, 1,430 persons who were Hindu and 177 persons who belonged to another church. 16,363 (or about 12.72% of the population) belonged to no church, are agnostic or atheist, and 7,855 persons (or about 6.11% of the population) did not answer the question. On 14 December 2014 the Haus der Religionen was inaugurated.


== Main sights ==

The structure of Bern's city centre is largely medieval and has been recognised by UNESCO as a Cultural World Heritage Site. Perhaps its most famous sight is the Zytglogge (Bernese German for "Time Bell"), an elaborate medieval clock tower with moving puppets. It also has an impressive 15th century Gothic cathedral, the Münster, and a 15th-century town hall. Thanks to 6 kilometres (4 miles) of arcades, the old town boasts one of the longest covered shopping promenades in Europe.
Since the 16th century, the city has had a bear pit, the Bärengraben, at the far end of the Nydeggbrücke to house its heraldic animals. The currently four bears are now kept in an open-air enclosure nearby, and two other young bears, a present by the Russian president, are kept in Dählhölzli zoo.The Federal Palace (Bundeshaus), built from 1857 to 1902, which houses the national parliament, government and part of the federal administration, can also be visited.
Albert Einstein lived in a flat at the Kramgasse 49, the site of the Einsteinhaus, from 1903 to 1905, the year in which the Annus Mirabilis papers were published.
The Rose Garden (Rosengarten), from which a scenic panoramic view of the medieval town centre can be enjoyed, is a well-kept Rosarium on a hill, converted into a park from a former cemetery in 1913.
There are eleven Renaissance allegorical statues on public fountains in the Old Town. Nearly all the 16th-century fountains, except the Zähringer fountain, which was created by Hans Hiltbrand, are the work of the Fribourg master Hans Gieng. One of the more interesting fountains is the Kindlifresserbrunnen (Bernese German: Child Eater Fountain), which is claimed to represent a Jew, the Greek god Chronos, or a Fastnacht figure meant to frighten disobedient children.Bern's most recent sight is the set of fountains in front of the Federal Palace. It was inaugurated on 1 August 2004.
The Universal Postal Union is situated in Bern.


=== Heritage sites of national significance ===
Bern is home to 114 Swiss heritage sites of national significance.It includes the entire Old Town, which is also a UNESCO World Heritage Site, and many sites within and around it. Some of the most notable in the Old Town include the Cathedral which was started in 1421 and is the tallest cathedral in Switzerland, the Zytglogge and Käfigturm towers, which mark two successive expansions of the Old Town, and the Holy Ghost Church, which is one of the largest Swiss Reformed churches in Switzerland. Within the Old Town, there are eleven 16th-century fountains, most attributed to Hans Gieng, that are on the list.
Outside the Old Town the heritage sites include the Bärengraben, the Gewerbeschule Bern (1937), the Eidgenössisches Archiv für Denkmalpflege, the Kirchenfeld mansion district (after 1881), the Thunplatzbrunnen, the Federal Mint building, the Federal Archives, the Swiss National Library, the Historical Museum (1894), Alpine Museum, Museum of Communication and Natural History Museum.
