text.wiki:
Bern [bɛrn] (listen) (Alemannic German: Bärn [b̥æːrn]; French: Berne [bɛʁn] (listen); Italian: Berna [ˈbɛrna]; Romansh: Berna [ˈbɛrnɐ] (listen)) is the de facto capital of Switzerland, referred to by the Swiss as their "federal city", in German Bundesstadt, French ville fédérale, and Italian città federale. With a population of about 140,000 (as of 2019), Bern is the fifth-most populous city in Switzerland. The Bern agglomeration, which includes 36 municipalities, had a population of 406,900 in 2014. The metropolitan area had a population of 660,000 in 2000. Bern is also the capital of the canton of Bern, the second-most populous of Switzerland's cantons.
The official language in Bern is (the Swiss variety of Standard) German, but the most-spoken language is an Alemannic Swiss German dialect, Bernese German.
In 1983, the historic old town (in German: Altstadt) in the centre of Bern became a UNESCO World Heritage Site.


== Etymology ==

The etymology of the name "Bern" is uncertain. According to the local legend, based on folk etymology, Berchtold V, Duke of Zähringen, the founder of the city of Bern, vowed to name the city after the first animal he met on the hunt, and this turned out to be a bear. It has long been considered likely that the city was named after the Italian city of Verona, which at the time was known as Bern in Middle High German. As a result of the finding of the Bern zinc tablet in the 1980s, it is now more common to assume that the city was named after a pre-existing toponym of Celtic origin, possibly *berna "cleft". The bear was the heraldic animal of the seal and coat of arms of Bern from at least the 1220s. The earliest reference to the keeping of live bears in the Bärengraben dates to the 1440s.


== History ==


=== Early history ===

No archaeological evidence that indicates a settlement on the site of today′s city centre prior to the 12th century has been found so far. In antiquity, a Celtic oppidum stood on the Engehalbinsel (peninsula) north of Bern, fortified since the second century BC (late La Tène period), thought to be one of the 12 oppida of the Helvetii mentioned by Caesar. During the Roman era, a Gallo-Roman vicus was on the same site. The Bern zinc tablet has the name Brenodor ("dwelling of Breno"). In the Early Middle Ages, a settlement in Bümpliz, now a city district of Bern, was some 4 km (2 mi) from the medieval city.
The medieval city is a foundation of the Zähringer ruling family, which rose to power in Upper Burgundy in the 12th century. According to 14th-century historiography (Cronica de Berno, 1309), Bern was founded in 1191 by Berthold V, Duke of Zähringen.
In 1218, after Berthold died without an heir, Bern was made a free imperial city by the Goldene Handfeste of Holy Roman Emperor Frederick II.


=== Old Swiss Confederacy ===

In 1353, Bern joined the Swiss Confederacy, becoming one of the eight cantons of the formative period of 1353 to 1481.
Bern invaded and conquered Aargau in 1415 and Vaud in 1536, as well as other smaller territories, thereby becoming the largest city-state north of the Alps; by the 18th century, it comprised most of what is today the canton of Bern and the canton of Vaud.
The city grew out towards the west of the boundaries of the peninsula formed by the river Aare. The Zytglogge tower marked the western boundary of the city from 1191 until 1256, when the Käfigturm took over this role until 1345. It was, in turn, succeeded by the Christoffelturm (formerly located close to the site of the modern-day railway station) until 1622. During the time of the Thirty Years' War, two new fortifications – the so-called big and small Schanze (entrenchment) – were built to protect the whole area of the peninsula.
After a major blaze in 1405, the city's original wooden buildings were gradually replaced by half-timbered houses and subsequently the sandstone buildings which came to be characteristic for the Old Town. Despite the waves of pestilence that hit Europe in the 14th century, the city continued to grow, mainly due to immigration from the surrounding countryside.


=== Modern history ===
Bern was occupied by French troops in 1798 during the French Revolutionary Wars, when it was stripped of parts of its territories. It regained control of the Bernese Oberland in 1802, and following the Congress of Vienna of 1814, it newly acquired the Bernese Jura. At this time, it once again became the largest canton of the Confederacy as it stood during the Restoration and until the secession of the canton of Jura in 1979.
Bern was made the Federal City (seat of the Federal Assembly) within the new Swiss federal state in 1848.
A number of congresses of the socialist First and Second Internationals were held in Bern, particularly during World War I when Switzerland was neutral; see Bern International.
The city's population rose from about 5,000 in the 15th century to about 12,000 by 1800 and to above 60,000 by 1900, passing the 100,000 mark during the 1920s.
Population peaked during the 1960s at 165,000 and has since decreased slightly, to below 130,000 by 2000.
As of September 2017, the resident population stood at 142,349, of which 100,000 were Swiss citizens and 42,349 (31%) resident foreigners. A further estimated 350,000 people live in the immediate urban agglomeration.


== Geography and climate ==


=== Topography ===

Bern lies on the Swiss plateau in the canton of Bern, slightly west of the centre of Switzerland and 20 km (12 mi) north of the Bernese Alps. The countryside around Bern was formed by glaciers during the most recent ice age. The two mountains closest to Bern are Gurten with a height of 864 m (2,835 ft) and Bantiger with a height of 947 m (3,107 ft). The site of the old observatory in Bern is the point of origin of the CH1903 coordinate system at 46°57′08.66″N 7°26′22.50″E.
The city was originally built on a hilly peninsula surrounded by the river Aare, but outgrew natural boundaries by the 19th century. A number of bridges have been built to allow the city to expand beyond the Aare.
Bern is built on very uneven ground. An elevation difference of up to 60 metres exists between the inner city districts on the Aare (Matte, Marzili) and the higher ones (Kirchenfeld, Länggasse).
Bern has an area, as of 2009, of 51.62 km2 (19.93 sq mi). Of this area, 9.79 km2 (3.78 sq mi) or 19.0% is used for agricultural purposes, while 17.33 km2 (6.69 sq mi) or 33.6% is forested. Of the rest of the land, 23.25 km2 (8.98 sq mi) or 45.0% is settled (buildings or roads), 1.06 km2 (0.41 sq mi) or 2.1% is either rivers or lakes, and 0.16 km2 (0.062 sq mi) or 0.3% is unproductive land.Of the developed area of Bern, 3.6% consists of industrial buildings, 21.7% housing and other buildings, and 12.6% is devoted to transport infrastructure. Power and water infrastructure, as well as other special developed areas, made up 1.1% of the city, while another 6.0% consists of parks, green belts, and sports fields.
Of Bern's total land area, 32.8% is heavily forested. Of the agricultural land, 14.3% is used for growing crops and 4.0% is designated to be used as pasture. Local rivers and streams provide all the water in the municipality.


=== Climate ===
According to the Köppen Climate Classification, Bern has a humid continental climate (Dfb) closely bordering on an oceanic climate (Cfb).
The closest weather station near Bern is located in the municipality of Zollikofen, about 5 kilometres (3 mi) north of the city centre. The warmest month for Bern is July, with a daily mean temperature of 18.3 °C (64.9 °F), and a daily maximum temperature of 24.3 °C (75.7 °F). The highest temperature recorded at Bern / Zollikofen is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), recorded in August 2003. On average, a temperature of 25 °C (77 °F) or above is recorded 40.7 days per year, and 6 days per year with a temperature of 30 °C (86 °F) or above at Zollikofen, and the warmest day reaches an average of 32.1 °C (89.8 °F).There are 103.7 days of air frost, and 22.3 ice days per year at Bern (Zollikofen) for the period of 1981–2010, as well as 14.1 days of snowfall, 36.7 days of snow cover per year and the average amount of snow measured per year is 52.6 centimetres (20.7 in). On average, January is the coldest month, with a daily mean temperature of −0.4 °C (31.3 °F), and a daily minimum temperature of −3.6 °C (25.5 °F). The lowest temperature ever recorded at Bern (Zollikofen) was −23.0 °C (−9.4 °F), recorded in February 1929, and typically the coldest temperature of the year reaches an average of −12.8 °C (9.0 °F) for the period of 1981–2010.


== Politics ==


=== Subdivisions ===
The municipality is administratively subdivided into six districts (Stadtteile), each of which consists of several quarters (Quartiere).


=== Government ===

The Municipal Council (de: Gemeinderat, fr: conseil municipal) constitutes the executive government of the City of Bern and operates as a collegiate authority. It is composed of five councillors (German: Gemeinderat/-rätin, French: conseiller/conseillère municipal(e)), each presiding over a directorate (de: Direktion, fr: direction) comprising several departments and bureaus. The president of the executive department acts as mayor (de: Stadtpräsident, fr: Le Maire). In the mandate period 2017–2020 (Legislatur) the Municipal Council is presided by Stadtpräsident Alec von Graffenried. Departmental tasks, coordination measures and implementation of laws decreed by the City Council are carried by the Municipal Council. The regular election of the Municipal Council by any inhabitant valid to vote is held every four years. Any resident of Bern allowed to vote can be elected as a member of the Municipal Council. Contrary to most other municipalities, the executive government in Berne is selected by means of a system of Proporz. The mayor is elected as such as well by public election while the heads of the other directorates are assigned by the collegiate. The executive body holds its meetings in the Erlacherhof, built by architect Albrecht Stürler after 1747.As of 2017, Bern's Municipal Council is made up of two representatives of the SP (Social Democratic Party), and one each of CVP (Christian Democratic Party), GFL (Grüne Freie Liste a.k.a. Green Free List, who is the newly elected mayor since 2017), and GB (Green Alliance of Berne), giving the left parties a very strong majority of four out of five seats. The last regular election was held on 27 November 2016/15 January 2017.

Dr. Jürg Wichtermann is State Chronicler (Staatsschreiber) since 2008. He has been elected by the collegiate.


=== Parliament ===

The City Council (de: Stadtrat, fr: Conseil de ville) holds legislative power. It is made up of 80 members, with elections held every four years. The City Council decrees regulations and by-laws that are executed by the Municipal Council and the administration. The delegates are selected by means of a system of proportional representation.
The sessions of the City Council are public. Unlike members of the Municipal Council, members of the City Council are not politicians by profession, and they are paid a fee based on their attendance. Any resident of Bern allowed to vote can be elected as a member of the City Council. The parliament holds its meetings in the Stadthaus (Town Hall).The last regular election of the City Council was held on 27 November 2016 for the mandate period (German: Legislatur, French: la législature) from 2017 to 2020. Currently the City Council consist of 24 members of the Social Democratic Party (SP/PS) including 2 members of the junior party JUSO, 9 Green Alliance of Berne (GB), 9 The Liberals (FDP/PLR), 9 Swiss People's Party (SVP/UDC), 8 Grüne Freie Liste (GFL) (Green Free List), 8 Green Liberal Party (glp/pvl) including one member of its junior party jglp, 3 Conservative Democratic Party (BDP/PBD), 2 Christian Democratic People's Party (CVP/PDC), 2 Evangelical People's Party (EVP/PEV), 2 Junge Alternative (JA!) (or Young Alternatives), 2 Alternative Linke Bern (AL), 1 Grüne Partei Bern – Demokratische Alternative (GPB-DA) (or Green Party Bern – Democratic Alternative), and 1 Swiss Party of Labour (PdA).
The following parties combine their parliamentary power in parliamentary groups (German: Fraktion(en)): AL and GPB-DA and PdA (4), SP and JUSO (24), GB and JA! (11), GFL and EVP (10), glp und jglp (8), BDP and CVP (5), FDP (9), and SVP (9). This gives the left parties an absolute majority of 49 seats.


=== National elections ===


==== National Council ====
In the 2019 federal election for the Swiss National Council the most popular party was the PS which received 28.7% (-5.6) of the vote. The next five most popular parties were the Green Party (25.2%, +7.9), the pvl (13.5%, +4.1), the UDC (9.5%, -2.9), PLR (4.2%, -2.8), and the BDP/PBD (7.0%). In the federal election a total of 49,030 votes were cast, and the voter turnout was 56%.In the 2015 federal election for the Swiss National Council the most popular party was the PS which received 34.3% of the vote. The next five most popular parties were the Green Party (17.4%), the UDC (12.4%), and the FDP/PLR (9.9%), glp/pvl (9.4%), and the BDP/PBD (7.0%). In the federal election, a total of 48,556 voters were cast, and the voter turnout was 56.0%.


=== International relations ===


==== Twin and sister cities ====
The Municipal Council of the city of Bern decided against having twinned cities except for a temporary (during the UEFA Euro 2008) cooperation with the Austrian city Salzburg.


== Demographics ==


=== Population ===
Bern has a population (as of December 2018) of 133,883.. About 34% of the population are resident foreign nationals. Over the 10 years between 2000 and 2010, the population changed at a rate of 0.6%. Migration accounted for 1.3%, while births and deaths accounted for −2.1%.Most of the population (as of 2000) speaks German (104,465 or 81.2%) as their first language, Italian is the second most common (5,062 or 3.9%) and French is the third (4,671 or 3.6%). There are 171 people who speak Romansh.As of 2008, the population was 47.5% male and 52.5% female. The population was made up of 44,032 Swiss men (35.4% of the population) and 15,092 (12.1%) non-Swiss men. There were 51,531 Swiss women (41.4%) and 13,726 (11.0%) non-Swiss women. Of the population in the municipality, 39,008 or about 30.3% were born in Bern and lived there in 2000. There were 27,573 or 21.4% who were born in the same canton, while 25,818 or 20.1% were born somewhere else in Switzerland, and 27,812 or 21.6% were born outside of Switzerland.

As of 2000, children and teenagers (0–19 years old) make up 15.1% of the population, while adults (20–64 years old) make up 65% and seniors (over 64 years old) make up 19.9%.As of 2000, there were 59,948 people who were single and never married in the municipality. There were 49,873 married individuals, 9,345 widows or widowers and 9,468 individuals who are divorced.

As of 2000, there were 67,115 private households in the municipality, and an average of 1.8 persons per household. There were 34,981 households that consist of only one person and 1,592 households with five or more people. In 2000, a total of 65,538 apartments (90.6% of the total) were permanently occupied, while 5,352 apartments (7.4%) were seasonally occupied and 1,444 apartments (2.0%) were empty. As of 2009, the construction rate of new housing units was 1.2 new units per 1000 residents.As of 2003 the average price to rent an average apartment in Bern was 1108.92 Swiss francs (CHF) per month (US$890, £500, €710 approx. exchange rate from 2003). The average rate for a one-room apartment was 619.82 CHF (US$500, £280, €400), a two-room apartment was about 879.36 CHF (US$700, £400, €560), a three-room apartment was about 1040.54 CHF (US$830, £470, €670) and a six or more room apartment cost an average of 2094.80 CHF (US$1680, £940, €1340). The average apartment price in Bern was 99.4% of the national average of 1116 CHF. The vacancy rate for the municipality, in 2010, was 0.45%.


=== Historic population ===
The historical population is given in the following chart:


=== Religion ===
From the 2000 census, 60,455 or 47.0% belonged to the Swiss Reformed Church, while 31,510 or 24.5% were Roman Catholic. Of the rest of the population, there were 1,874 members of an Orthodox church (or about 1.46% of the population), there were 229 persons (or about 0.18% of the population) who belonged to the Christian Catholic Church, and there were 5,531 persons (or about 4.30% of the population) who belonged to another Christian church. There were 324 persons (or about 0.25% of the population) who were Jewish, and 4,907 (or about 3.81% of the population) who were Muslim. There were 629 persons who were Buddhist, 1,430 persons who were Hindu and 177 persons who belonged to another church. 16,363 (or about 12.72% of the population) belonged to no church, are agnostic or atheist, and 7,855 persons (or about 6.11% of the population) did not answer the question. On 14 December 2014 the Haus der Religionen was inaugurated.


== Main sights ==

The structure of Bern's city centre is largely medieval and has been recognised by UNESCO as a Cultural World Heritage Site. Perhaps its most famous sight is the Zytglogge (Bernese German for "Time Bell"), an elaborate medieval clock tower with moving puppets. It also has an impressive 15th century Gothic cathedral, the Münster, and a 15th-century town hall. Thanks to 6 kilometres (4 miles) of arcades, the old town boasts one of the longest covered shopping promenades in Europe.
Since the 16th century, the city has had a bear pit, the Bärengraben, at the far end of the Nydeggbrücke to house its heraldic animals. The currently four bears are now kept in an open-air enclosure nearby, and two other young bears, a present by the Russian president, are kept in Dählhölzli zoo.The Federal Palace (Bundeshaus), built from 1857 to 1902, which houses the national parliament, government and part of the federal administration, can also be visited.
Albert Einstein lived in a flat at the Kramgasse 49, the site of the Einsteinhaus, from 1903 to 1905, the year in which the Annus Mirabilis papers were published.
The Rose Garden (Rosengarten), from which a scenic panoramic view of the medieval town centre can be enjoyed, is a well-kept Rosarium on a hill, converted into a park from a former cemetery in 1913.
There are eleven Renaissance allegorical statues on public fountains in the Old Town. Nearly all the 16th-century fountains, except the Zähringer fountain, which was created by Hans Hiltbrand, are the work of the Fribourg master Hans Gieng. One of the more interesting fountains is the Kindlifresserbrunnen (Bernese German: Child Eater Fountain), which is claimed to represent a Jew, the Greek god Chronos, or a Fastnacht figure meant to frighten disobedient children.Bern's most recent sight is the set of fountains in front of the Federal Palace. It was inaugurated on 1 August 2004.
The Universal Postal Union is situated in Bern.


=== Heritage sites of national significance ===
Bern is home to 114 Swiss heritage sites of national significance.It includes the entire Old Town, which is also a UNESCO World Heritage Site, and many sites within and around it. Some of the most notable in the Old Town include the Cathedral which was started in 1421 and is the tallest cathedral in Switzerland, the Zytglogge and Käfigturm towers, which mark two successive expansions of the Old Town, and the Holy Ghost Church, which is one of the largest Swiss Reformed churches in Switzerland. Within the Old Town, there are eleven 16th-century fountains, most attributed to Hans Gieng, that are on the list.
Outside the Old Town the heritage sites include the Bärengraben, the Gewerbeschule Bern (1937), the Eidgenössisches Archiv für Denkmalpflege, the Kirchenfeld mansion district (after 1881), the Thunplatzbrunnen, the Federal Mint building, the Federal Archives, the Swiss National Library, the Historical Museum (1894), Alpine Museum, Museum of Communication and Natural History Museum.

== Sports ==

Bern was the site of the 1954 Football (Soccer) World Cup Final, a huge upset for the Hungarian Golden Team, who were beaten 3–2 by West Germany. The football team BSC Young Boys is based in Bern at the Stade de Suisse Wankdorf, which also was one of the venues for the European football championship 2008 in which it hosted 3 matches.
FC Breitenrain Bern, founded in 1994, also play in Bern.SC Bern is the major ice hockey team of Bern which plays in the PostFinance Arena. They compete in the National League (NL), the highest league in Switzerland. The team has ranked highest in attendance for a European hockey team for more than a decade. The PostFinance Arena was the main host of the 2009 IIHF Ice Hockey World Championship, including the opening game and the final of the tournament.
The PostFinance Arena was also the host of the 2011 European Figure Skate Championships.
Bern Cardinals is the baseball and softball team of Bern, which plays at the Allmend
Bern Grizzlies is the American football club in Bern and plays at Athletics Arena Wankdorf.
Bern was a candidate to host the 2010 Winter Olympics, but withdrew its bid in September 2002 after a referendum was passed that showed that the bid was not supported by locals. Those games were eventually awarded to Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada.
RC Bern is the local rugby club (since 1972) and plays at the Allmend. The ladies team was founded in 1995.
The locality of Bremgartenwald was home to the Bremgarten Circuit, the Grand Prix motor racing course that at one time hosted the Swiss Grand Prix.
Bern Bears is an NGO Basketball Club since 2010 in city of Bern.The Swiss Grand Prix was held on the Circuit Bremgarten street track from 1950-1954, with MotoGP also running their Swiss motorcycle Grand Prix from 1949 to 1954. The circuit eventually fell into disrepair after Switzerland banned motorports after the 1955 Le Mans Disaster, but they made an amendment in 2015 to host electric racing, which is how the Swiss ePrix happened in 2019.


== Economy ==
As of  2010, Bern had an unemployment rate of 3.3%. As of 2008, there were 259 people employed in the primary economic sector and about 59 businesses involved in this sector. 16,413 people were employed in the secondary sector and there were 950 businesses in this sector. 135,973 people were employed in the tertiary sector, with 7,654 businesses in this sector.In 2008 the total number of full-time equivalent jobs was 125,037. The number of jobs in the primary sector was 203, of which 184 were in agriculture and 19 were in forestry or lumber production. The number of jobs in the secondary sector was 15,476 of which 7,650 or (49.4%) were in manufacturing, 51 or (0.3%) were in mining and 6,389 (41.3%) were in construction. The number of jobs in the tertiary sector was 109,358. In the tertiary sector; 11,396 or 10.4% were in wholesale or retail sales or the repair of motor vehicles, 10,293 or 9.4% were in the movement and storage of goods, 5,090 or 4.7% were in a hotel or restaurant, 7,302 or 6.7% were in the information industry, 8,437 or 7.7% were the insurance or financial industry, 10,660 or 9.7% were technical professionals or scientists, 5,338 or 4.9% were in education and 17,903 or 16.4% were in health care.In 2000, there were 94,367 workers who commuted into the municipality and 16,424 workers who commuted away. The municipality is a net importer of workers, with about 5.7 workers entering the municipality for every one leaving. Of the working population, 50.6% used public transport to get to work, and 20.6% used a private car.


== Education ==

The University of Bern, whose buildings are mainly located in the Länggasse quarter, is located in Bern, as well as the University of Applied Sciences (Fachhochschule) and several vocations schools.
In Bern, about 50,418 or (39.2%) of the population have completed non-mandatory upper secondary education, and 24,311 or (18.9%) have completed additional higher education (either university or a Fachhochschule). Of the 24,311 who completed tertiary schooling, 51.6% were Swiss men, 33.0% were Swiss women, 8.9% were non-Swiss men and 6.5% were non-Swiss women.The canton of Bern school system provides one year of non-obligatory kindergarten, followed by six years of primary school. This is followed by three years of obligatory lower secondary school where the pupils are separated according to ability and aptitude. Following the lower secondary pupils may attend additional schooling or they may enter an apprenticeship.During the 2009–10 school year, there were a total of 10,979 pupils attending classes in Bern. There were 89 kindergarten classes with a total of 1,641 pupils in the municipality. Of the kindergarten pupils, 32.4% were permanent or temporary residents of Switzerland (not citizens) and 40.2% have a different mother language than the classroom language. The municipality had 266 primary classes and 5,040 pupils. Of the primary pupils, 30.1% were permanent or temporary residents of Switzerland (not citizens) and 35.7% have a different mother language than the classroom language. During the same year, there were 151 lower secondary classes with a total of 2,581 pupils. There were 28.7% who were permanent or temporary residents of Switzerland (not citizens) and 32.7% have a different mother language than the classroom language.Bern is home to 8 libraries. These libraries include; the Schweiz. Nationalbibliothek/ Bibliothèque nationale suisse, the Universitätsbibliothek Bern, the Kornhausbibliotheken Bern, the BFH Wirtschaft und Verwaltung Bern, the BFH Gesundheit, the BFH Soziale Arbeit, the Hochschule der Künste Bern, Gestaltung und Kunst and the Hochschule der Künste Bern, Musikbibliothek. There was a combined total (as of 2008) of 10,308,336 books or other media in the libraries, and in the same year a total of 2,627,973 items were loaned out.As of 2000, there were 9,045 pupils in Bern who came from another municipality, while 1,185 residents attended schools outside the municipality.


== Transport ==

The public transport in and around Bern is operated by BERNMOBIL, which is integrated into the fare network libero with coordinated timetables, which in itself covers the area of canton of Bern and Solothurn. The fare network includes any mode of public transport, such as any kind of train (including the urban S-Bahn), PostAuto buses, trams, buses (either trolleybuses or motorized buses) and others. Fares are based on the number of zones crossed during a specified time and are independent of the mode of transport or the number of connections. The central part of Bern, excluding Bümpliz, Betlehem, Bottigen, Brünnen, and Riedbach in the west of the municipality, is part of the fare zone 100.
Bern's central railway station Bahnhof Bern) (formerly known as Hauptbahnhof Bern) is not only the central network nucleus of Bern, but also of the whole urban and inter-cantonal region. It connects the city to the urban, national and international railways network and is Switzerland's second most busy railway station (202,600 passengers per working day in 2014).
A funicular railway leads from the Marzili district to the Bundeshaus. The Marzilibahn funicular is, with a length of 106 m (348 ft), the second shortest public railway in Europe after the Zagreb funicular.
Several Aare bridges connect the old parts of the city with the newer districts outside of the peninsula.
Bern is well connected to other cities by several motorways (A1, A12, A6).
Bern is also served by Bern Airport, located outside the city near the town of Belp. The regional airport, colloquially called Bern-Belp or Belpmoos, is connected to several European cities. Additionally Zurich Airport, Geneva Airport and EuroAirport Basel Mulhouse Freiburg also serve as international gateways, all reachable within less than two hours by train or car from Bern.

Rosegarden is a must-see if you're around Bern.From here you can get a panoramic view of the city.When we visited Bern was beautiful with autumn colours and from here we could best capture that beauty.It is at a walking distance from Bearpit garden and entrance is free
This is a park that you can easily find elsewhere. May be related to visiting season, there are not many roses in the garden. Not fascinating.

We really enjoyed our walk and time in the rose garden. It’s been there a long time and is a gem in the area. It was a beautiful day and the time spend outdoors was perfect. Many roses still in bloom in October along with lots of other flowers.

A beautiful rose garden set up on a hill opposite old town across the beautiful river running around the old part of town. This place has a kids play ground and plenty of open space for picnics. Also a Restaurant that has a small menu but what they have is absolutely delicious.
Beautiful rose garden with almost infinite types of roses. Great smells all around and lots of space in the park to sit back and relax
This was quite the uphill hike on a hot day but the gardens were beautiful to hang out in a shady spot. A great view of the city too.

My absolutely favorite garden. I love the view and I can stay there the whole day enjoying the view of the old town from above as well as the different roses all over the place. It's my kind of paradise.🌷
I was there in late August and the roses were amazing! Many, may varieties and the fragrance was heaven. Very pretty park setting, a lovely place to visit.
Just amazing .. the view .. the garden ... Fantastic ... A very beautiful and nice place to spend some quiet time
The garden is lovely of course, but the view is really amazing from here You see the city laid out its excellent. Its worth the drive to see the garden and the view and take some nice pictures too.

Nice hike up a steep hill to get to this place. Can access from the top also without too much walking. Lots of different types of Rose's are in the garden. But did not look like they take time to cut and trim the Roses. Nice place to take pictures and have a view of the city
The Rosengarten is delightful. Many varieties of wonderfully scented roses. Lovely water feature with lily pads and nice views of river and old town.

Cafe at the top, great view too!! there are plenty of trees and shade in families having picnics in the park there are lots of Cheerios and playgrounds for kids to play on it's about a 15 minute walk up from the beer kits if you don't take the main little trial that goes up

The park itself is not much to see, there are some roses of course but not that many that they motivate a visit. You visit either to have a pick-nick on the generous lawns or to admire the view over Aare and the old city. Coming from the city the easiest is to take bus 10 to
A must see for any visitors to Bern with expansive views over the whole city. Birds eye views over the city was also accompanied with beautiful rows of roses .

Don´t hesitate to go a little bit far than usually or to use local bus, to get this garden. It is located up the river Aare on your left hand from Bärengraben where any tourist must go one day. You will surprised how nice view of the city is from this place. Many official

The walk up from the bridge is worth it but it’s steep so take your time. If you enjoy roses they have a lovely selection and when in flower the fragrances are gorgeous. The view over the old city, river and bridge is a tourist photographers delight. There is a cafe

To be fair we walked up to the Rose Garden on a very hot August day 30C. By the time we reached the Rose Garden, all we were fit for was a seat and a coffee with some delicious cake from the cafe. There are plenty of seats with a good view of the city and photo opportunities
I enjoyed my time in the garden, it was because and peaceful, there was a good view of the old city from there , I enjoyed it and recommend it!

all these medieval roofs of the old city & its churches, a peninsula surrounded by the Aare river, are quite impressive. the government gardeners do a great job keeping the garden-like park & all the flowers in good condition.
amazing overview of the city down below. beautifully kept and very peaceful. actually a nice little gem in the hustle bustle of the city.

We took a bus their walked up the hill came to Rose Garden with so many varieties of Roses in bloom but the best of all was the view of Bern a must to get up that hill (easy coming down )
A nice walk up from the Bear Park. Beautiful gardens with an excellent view over the river and the old city of Bern.

It's kind of a steep, though not long, hike up to the rose garden, but you get rewarded with a great view of Bern. There were some but not many rose blooms when we visited but there were other flowers and it's a great place to relax and cool off on a hot day. The restaurant
A beautiful park with the beautiful view of the city. Great for picnics with the entire family. It also has a nice restaurant and a playground

Nice view. Great space for the locals; library, playground green space with chairs scattered throughout. Roses were in full bloom end of June. We hiked it. A good meandering climb up using streets and a more direct descent using a foot path. We were there during a heat wave;
Pretty gardens overall. Some lovely blooms to see. However, once you have seen the Butchart gardens in Canada I am afraid everything else appears average.

My wife really wanted to go and for me, it was, really just to see Roses? At the end, however, I must admit that it was fine. The parking is very close to the gate. During the festival, the ticket prices are a bit more expenses, but a lot is happening, You can buy beer,

The day was beautiful and it was a Great Wall. The garden is a small park with a mix of paths, flowers and fountains. There is restaurant where you can eat or just have a drink.

We walked through the gardens on a beautiful sunny weekend afternoon, too early for the roses but the spring growth on them was looking healthy, a lot of people enjoying some r&r, great views of the city and an easy walk down to cross the river into the old town.
The Garden is a great viewing place of the city. It was too early to see roses, however there were a couple of attractive tulip gardens.

We took a day trip to Bern from Luzern. Get a map from the Tourist Information at the train station. On the map, there's direction how to get to the Rose Garden. Can't see any rose blooming but there were other types of flowers. Nice to have a picnic here or just come to see

Would be better In summer when roses out but the spring flowers were very pretty, and great views of the city of Bern. Also the restaurant is very attractive – one can sit outside or inside depending on the weather.

If you like the beatiful view over the old city of Bern, thats the place to go. If you are not to hungry, thats the place to go, as portion size is not in relation to the price - but - the quality of the food was fine and the service as well

Great view over Bern, you can sit and drink a coffee or just walk around the garden. Whatever you do, the view is worth it.

Walked to this site today from our hotel and the views were over Bern were spectacular. There was a light sprinkling of snow over the gardens too. Unfortunately due to the season there were no roses however the views made up for it. We also had a hot drink at the restaurant/

The staff is rude and unfriendl. The park itself is great for kids, beautiful to look at. But the restaurant I will avoid. Really bad!
Very peaceful place to explore.Bring your sarong, snacks, book and enjoy the grass! My advice is to catch the sunset.

Been here a few times in different seasons over the past few years and it’s still utterly beautiful. It’s a lovely place to come and get away from the city and it has spectacular views down onto the old town and the river.

Find Albert Einstein on the park bench and enjoy magnificent views of the city and River Aare. I was looking for scene locations from the BBC version of Smiley's people - this is where Toby Esterhase met with his Russian mark.

We walked all over Bern and this was one of our favorite spots! There were still many roses blooming here and fountains everywhere! You can see all of Bern from up here as well! It’s a great view and you can sit with Einstein and rest if you like! Pack a picnic if you wish ..
Lovely garden, but the main aim of us stopping there was to get a view of the city of bern. Good lookout point. We also had coffee and hot chocolate at the cafe, which were ok.

If you walked through the city center to the Bärengraben anyway, the walk up the hill to Rosengarten is well worth it on a fine day. Wonderful view of the old town and the Aare loop, a park and a cafe if you want. Also serviced by city bus.
I took a walk out of Bern through one of the bridges, the Rose Garden offers a beautiful view of Bern from here, there is also a very good restaurant with cozy setting.
Well worth a visit for both the view over the city and the nice gardens. Also has a coffee shop and toilets.

Absolutely beautiful roses and garden. There is a coffee shop here and an Einstein bench. Great views overlooking the city of Bern. Free bathrooms located on the grounds as well.

Not really the season for roses, but there were a few. The view is awesome and it seemed like a nice place to hang out and have a bite to eat and just enjoy some nice weather

A short bus ride from the Railway Station would take you here. Its probably THE SPOT for all visitors to this city. A well-maintained garden full of activity for all ages, giving a scenic view of the old church and the city.
Lovely place the sun was shining had a couple of beers overlooking the old town, park very well kept with great view over the old town.

For the flower lover, this is well worth the walk. Be aware that the road up to the garden if you are walking is pretty steep, but OH the reward. It was gorgeous and the views of Old Town Bern is an added bonus. It is free to enter this beautiful little park.

We came here twice, once in the late afternoon and once in the next morning, it is a convenient bus ride from downtown or you can walk here. The rose garden is nice but not extraordinary but you have a nice view of the city.

The Rosegarten is a must see when you visit Bern. In addition to being very pretty it has a wonderful view of the Old Town.

You can have a relaxing walk among all the beautiful roses. When we went they were getting past their best but would be magnificent in summer. It is a very steep path to the Rose Garden but there is a bus which takes you to the rear of the park
Nice grounds and nice panoramic view of the city and valley below. Long, at times steep, walk to, though, from the Altstadt.

It's a pretty garden (not just roses, but mostly) and a nice spot to wander about. A bit outside the town center, and a bit of a hike to get up there, but well worth it for the gardens and the views of Bern.

Is a long way to reach the top but the view is breathtaking, absolutely worth it. The roses were probably the least thing to watch there

Situated above the Old Town of Bern, the Rose Garden offers beautiful views of the city as well as a lovey park to relax in. A children’s playground and restaurant is an added bonus. Free clean toilet
Well worth a trip here. Fantastic views over the city of Bern and a really nice restaurant/ cafe on site. Came back here at night too too see Bern lit up. Amazing.

To see gardens with beautiful flowers are a nice way to start our tour . Nice impressive collection. The area also afford views of the city and the body of water that flows between it. Good to take photos, or just spend a longer time.

We enjoyed walking around the rose garden very much. Many roses were in bloom. The park is very well maintained. The views of Bern are amazing. We did not eat at the restaurant but it looks very nice.

A must visit when in Bern. There you see different kinds of roses that actually smell. The fountain is beautiful with benches to sit around and relax. On Sundays you can pick nick there on the grass and let the children run around. The views of Bern from above are breathtaking.
This is a nice rose garden area to visit. It is very laid back. The view of Bern from this location is really great.
Enjoy a botanical experience while dining above the beautiful city of Bern! Delicious food, wonderful service, followed by a relaxing stroll through the gardens! Be part of this Bern experience!

The garden is magnificent, and the view of the town is even better. I would really recommend the walk up from the old town.

Rosengarten, as the name tells, is a garden full of different kinds of roses. Once you arrive to the bear park, there is the sign to go up to Rosengarten. There is a steep path to follow, but the beauty of the place pays for your effort! However there is also another street that
The view from the garden is outstanding. There is a coffee shop and worth spending some time. Also parking easily available.
Love to see different kinds of roses? Want a bird view over Bern while enjoying sunset moments? Rosengarten is the place to go.

It is easy access from station by bus. If you stay hotels in Bern, you probably receive free ticket of bus. At early morning, a lot of tour travelers came to garden because of free of charge and beautiful scenery.
Fantastic rose photos and lovely atmosphere to relax for a bit before before going on to the next tourit attraction.
A beautiful view above Bern. Worth the effort to walk up the hill and the cafe was quite good at the top. Definitely should see if in town

We waited more than 2 hours for our food! Just because you have a nice view does not give you the right to have crappy staff, bad food and high prices. I definitively cannot reconmend this place!

Perfect spot to see the downtown of Bern. Nice restaurant on the top of the hill is worth visiting. Strawberry cake very good! Beautiful also in the evening!

Unforgettable garden, size of a football field with huge beds of every type of rose plus lawns and a killer view of the old city below. They also Jaya great restaurant in the garden. It’s utterly fabulous
Beautiful view of Bern - steps up are awfully steep but worth the effort. Loved all the flowers and the bench with the statue of Einstein is a must for photos.
Easy to get to by foot or public transport, the Rosengarten offers a place to relax with Tea Rooms and excellent photo opportunities across the old city Bern

Its a beautiful place full of all kind of roses. Excellent place to hang around with kids , family and friends. It offers a great view of the city as well. It also have a kids play area and a restaurant.
Vantage point to overlook city landscape and buildings,with river Rrae flowing through.See community gardens below being maintained.
Spectacular view onto old town. Nice restaurant too. Lovely walk up from Bärengraben. May also be reached by bus.

Absolute quiet peaceful place. Take a piece of cloth to spread on lawns and something to eat(not too messy) and enjoy the view ,nature and quiet. The restaurant on garden is also very good. Bus no. 12 goes there from zentrum.

This is a must-visit in Bern. The roses were in full bloom in June - but the location also provided a great view of the picturesque old town seated by the winding river. The weather was also wonderful and its a short and comfortable walk to the Bärengraben.

We visited this rose garden in May 2018 and enjoyed all the flower varieties in bloom. The garden is easily reached by public transport. The garden is located near a wonderful park with an overview of Bern and the Aare River. A nice place to visit.

The rose garden itself wasn’t too amazing, but the views over bern that you can get from the garden are beautiful! We also ate at the restaurant at the top of the Rose garden which was the perfect stop to enjoy the views further.

Must see. A beautiful place with beautiful plants and flowers. If you are in the area this is a must visit.
Best view of Bern. You can walk from there to Einstein house and later have a dinner in Verdi Restaurant.

It's easy to arrive using public transportation (bus number 10). Don't worth go walking because the rosegarden is located on the upper part of the city. The garden has many variety of flowers and colours. A good place to take photos or make a picnic.
Short climb to Rose Garden and you can find a nice restaurant with amazing view on the all Old Town. This is place that you do want to leave. if i can have more time, i will stay where forever
The rose garden is a nice garden with amazing views of the city. You can find the Einstein statue located at the entrance on the way up. Its a nice place to hang around.
Not that hard going up.Have a coffee or lunch at the restaurant.Just chill. Nice for a sunny afternoon.Playground for kids included.

Very nice garden to walk around and enjoy during a visit to Bern. Flowers are nice and the garden is quiet but very scenic.

A good place for a picnic. The rose garden is well maintained and a lot of families are there when the weather is nice. You also have a good view on the old city, because the rose garden is situated on top of a hill across the river.

Probably the best view point of Bern’s old town. It’s a must see especially in spring when all roses start to bloom.

Yes, even in winter the rosengarten is enjoyable. But from late spring to late fall it turns to be a fairytale. I can only recommend
May be the best part of this park is its very nice views of Bern historical area. You can grab all the old city in your camera lens!

Always covered with beautiful seasonal flowers, the Rose Garden is one of the nicest places in Bern with a very good Restaurant and a stunning view over the Old Town. Perfect place to sit down or stroll around after having visited the Old Town of Bern or after Shopping.
If you go at Bern and you do not visite Rose Garden ..its the biggest mistake you can do ...beautiful place ..i really find peace here .

My boyfriend brought me here after we returned to Bern the place we met. It was covered in snow and looked so nice although it was night lights lit the place up and the views were beautiful. He proposed to me on the observation tower overlooking the wonderful view of the city.

Beautiful roses in bloom, good playground for kids and restaurant with great food next to it. Wonderful view over the old town of Bern too.
Amazing place to go and get a beautiful view of the city, even if it's a cloudy day the view is pretty good! :)

Check up when sunset today and come to Rosen Garten to get wonderful experience in city Bern. There is nice restaurant up there, but for nice view from panoramic window I can suggest reservations.

The flowers were beautiful but the main attraction is the wonderful view of the old city. In good weather I could spend hours here.
We had two meals at this restaurant. Food was outstanding,and the location and view great. You can't go wrong.

Very good garden with a beautiful view of the old town of bern.... has an excellent play area for kids....

The view from here is second only to the one from the top of the Cathederal, but the walk up the hill is easier and worth the effort. At the top you get a view of the old city as well as the rose garden where you can sit and rest for a while. You can even sit with a statue of

I have been living close to Bern for a couple of weeks, been in town for a couple of times but never had the opportunity to see the Rosengarten. It is not a big garden, but a nice park, with a lot of (370 plants, 130 different types) roses. but i think the more interesting part

At the recommendation of some one who has dined here before we had lunch at this hilltop restaurant. Exceptional!!!! The view is not to be believed. You can eat outdoors with a view of the city but also of the country and mountains. It's an amazing spot. The food was
If you're in town and want to capture Bern in one view without leaving the city, come here. There's a simple restaurant which serves some meals and drinks, too.
One of the prettiest places I ever visited. The view is absolutely breathtaking ! A Great place to bring a picnic or just enjoy a cup of coffee overlooking the Beautiful Bern!
Very nice park with the best view point over the City. The restaurant at the park serves delicious local dishes. In Walking distance to the Old Town of Bern.
August seems to be a hot month when we visited this year but a sunny day is needed to visit a restaurant with a garden of roses and flowers!
Ideal for a relaxing stop and great view from the top. The garden itself can't be among the top botanical gardens, its more about the view of the old city.

By the end of August the roses were past their best but still provided a little colour. The main reason for visiting are the views over the city and river, the walk up isn't long and it is a good path, but it is uphill. We didn't visit the restaurant at the top, but it appeared

The walk up was a tad tiring but worth it for the view of the city. We definitely took the opportunity for a photo shoot up there especially since it was such a clear, nice day. I was a bit confused about the 'rose garden' part since I guess I was expecting more roses, but

We walked up to the rose garden on a steep cobblestoned path. Hard going but well worth the effort. The roses had basically finished but the view was fantastic. The is a restaurant in the gardens that has sit down lunch and also some take away. An excellent view of the Swiss
Beautiful view of Bern's old town and the river. I'd say best view in town! I can highly recommend the walk up there, you will get some great pictures.
This is a great place to come a see a view of the city of Bern after visiting the Bear garden. Enjoy the gardens and take a drink or a meal before descending back into the city centre.
Nice little well kept park with a restaurant and coffee shop, but it's worth the visit purely for great views across the city

Lovely little garden and a nice restaurant for a lunch with friends or boyfriend. Price are not cheap but the food is good even if the menu is a bit inconsistent. Service is good but slow and is not a place if you are in hurry. note: There is no parking near, very few places are

If you choose to walk up to the Rosengarten, wear sturdy shoes. I think there's an alternative entrance at the top of the hill, which would be best for those with limited mobility. The roses are nice and the park is pretty but the view of the town and river are spectacular.

If you need to burn some calories after eating too much, consider walking up the STEEP cobblestone path to the Rose Garden after dinner for sunset. Not only can you take photos of the city for your scrapbook/photo book of the Old Town and winding river, there are hundreds of

Perfect for a summer evening. From here you have the most beautiful view of Berne, with the old town in front of you and the Gurten in the background. You can go have a drink in the restaurant or just sit on the grass or the wall and relax.
The rose garden does not consisted out of many roses. The walk to the garden was kinda long walk (steep path). The view however was nice.
It is a kind of park rather than a rose garden, so don't expect to see too many roses (well, there are some). It gives you a nice view of the city if you like taking pictures.

The Rosengarten is not breathtaking by any stretch but it is a lovely garden. It also offers a very nice view overlooking Old Town. As you would expect, the cafe is a bit pricey but it may be convenient or fun to have a drink or lunch there.

It was one of the main attraction of the town but when i reached there I found it to be really over hyped. The views of old town Bern are good but not mesmerizing. The garden is small and have roses planted but that also is not much. It is good for locals to hangout but nothing
Nice garden with lovely flowers. Great place to spend some time. Also, there is an amazing view on the city.

The rose garden is worth visiting for many reasons. There are fabulous views over Bern when you reach the top. The gardens are beautifully laid out. The garden is a recipient of cherry trees from Japan.

The Rose Garden sits on a hill looking down upon the old city of Bern. The garden was a refreshing place where you can take in the beauty of Bern. There were people picnicking in the garden and there is even a restaurant (unfortunately, we didn't stop). A word of caution, if

Good spot for meandering through the various gardens plus a bang up view of the surrounding countryside. It's an uphill walk, steep for some, but you can take a tram or drive here, too. Nice place for a picnic.

If you want to see Bern - it's from this vantage point! Walking through the gardens in June, people were having picnics, lilies in the pond and roses of amazing colour everywhere. Then you reach the view point, and it is remarkable. You could stand there forever!

The Rose Garden is relatively small but the setting above the city of Bern is wonderful.There is a restaurant where you can enjoy some refreshments and the view. The roses are nice, but not particularly extensive, but the setting itself makes this a must see when you are in Bern.
You may love Roses - and find them, you may be Interesse in history - and be informedm, you may be thirsty and get a Beer. And you may like to observiert People - and you will finde them.
Make sure to take the walk up the steep stone path to get there. Once there the view is fantastic with birds and butterflies all around.

The rose garden was both gorgeous to look at and wonderful to smell. Unlike most roses nowadays, these truly had a fantastic scent. And early in the morning it is so peaceful, it is almost like being in church. Good views, too.
The Rose Garden has a delightful collection of hundred's of rose varieties and a spectacular view of the city. I visit there every time I am in Bern,
Very pretty for a sunny afternoon. Superb views of the old city of Bern. Good place to read a book or to make exercises.

This garden lies on a hill, close to the old centre of Bern. The garden gathers in one place over 200 varieties of roses and it also hosts other species of flowers and trees. There is also a nice pond surrounded by alleys with benches and the view from the top offers a great
Beautiful views. Good food and wonderful gardens. Kids playground is very good and the view on the old town is wow.
Pretty area with a great view of Bern old city and river Aare. A steep walk up but if taken at a slow pace if you are not fit, it is manageable.
Definitely a climb to get up to this park, but well worth it. There's a playground for the kids, a nice cafe, and a fantastic view over all of Bern and its river.
The rose garden gives a panoramic view of the quaint Swiss city of Bern, and in June, the roses are wonderful. There a lovely cafe and s playground as well!
Rest on the grass among the trees and lovely roses; lunch with amazing views over the city. The restaurant menu is more than adequate. Portions can be large

If you wanna visit one of the best view points of the city you have to sweat a little. Located at almost the top of the hill you have to climb a bit (walk up) and you'll find also a restaurant, a playground for kids and a very satisfying view of the city and river. Enjoy!
Absolutely a lovely place for a picnic or a walk in the afternoon followed by staying in the nearby Cafe/Resturant for the sunset. !

Rose Garden (Rosengarten) was a part of the guided tour I was on recently, which incorporated much of the old town of Bern. It is a beautiful place to visit, a gem if you will, with some amazing views of the city. It's immaculately kept, and offers the ideal place for weddings
Take the bus here.. it drops you off right outside.. great tea place there to sit outside and look at the view over Bern .. especially at sunset..
Best place for afternoon with kids. Wonderful view of the old city and a great cafe. What else can you want? Well, parking. Had some trouble finding a parking space in the popular afternoon hours.

The very steep walking trail up to the area of the rose garden on a hot afternoon was proving extremely popular with the Sunday visitors and once you reach the level at which the garden is laid out in bloom season it is a pleasant place to sit and recover from the exertions and

A great place to relax sitting on the grass after to visit the old town of Bern. Its hard to reach (more if you already had walk around the coty before) but the view actually worth it. You can see ALL the coty with the cathetral and the River, its os amazing

Becoz of seeing fabulous red roses in Zurich, I was very excited when planning to go to this Rosegarten in Bern. Unfortunately, it seemed like not yet reach the peak time of roses, the flowers in the garden not as pretty as I expected 😭 but when we walked further, there's a

Didn't marvel me as much as the other parts of Bern did, went in April, there were no roses, maybe was in the right place at the wrong time. Did enjoy a Beer at the Restaurant Rosengarten which has an excellent view of The city of Bern.

I love gardens. There were some things blooming in early May but I imagine there's more going on now. They have nice gardens and a nice fountain. We had beverages on the patio at the restaurant. Which is terrific because it overlooks the city. It's a fabulous view. It's a
The views from and of the rosen Garten are spectacular. You can get some very beautiful pictures in the gardens as well as views of the city from the gardens.
Beautiful and good place to relax, this garden sits on a hill that you can see the whole city of Bern.

Laid out over a large area, the rosengarten at Bern is a short walk from the old town. The gates are never closed, so you can go there after dinner too. There are a large variety of roses well laid out, with plenty of greenery between. There is a marvelous view of the old town
No roses in a rose garden! But had a good view of old town! A must go place! Free entry, place to have a picnic!

You can't get higher and closer to overlook the old town of Berne. The beautiful park comes with an excellent view and a good restaurant with lots of outside seatings. Afterwards you can reach downtown Berne in a short 5 minutes walk downhill.

I went to the garden at the end of april and there were no roses there. Although the lack of roses, i think the the view from the top is really nice and has a lot of space to sit on the grass and enjoy a sunny day. But it might be a better ideia to visit it when the roses ate

Awesome view of bern city. We went ther in month of May. So there were no roses but other flora were nice. Nicely maintained. And good place to sit out relax and read books in free time. There is a small play area for kids. Which my kids (6 yrs and 10 yrs) enjoyed. If u are

There were no roses at this point of time. Was a bit disappointed. But still the view of the city with its houses and cathedral was simply fantastic. The garden is very small to the hype that was created around it. But one gets a very clear view of the UNESCO site
This is located high above the city and offers a great view. The grounds are well landscaped and maintained. It is clear that residents of Bern come to play and relax. Great spot. Be sure to visit.

The Rose Garden is a beautiful park and restaurant on the hill overlooking the original gate bridge into the city of Bern. We were accompanied by a Bern Tourism official to this location. The location is elevated and a steep walk that many may not want to make from the bridge

Wonderful park where it is so relaxing to walk around and admire the great amount of roses. The view to the old town of Bern from there is simply breathtaking. Take a stroll in the evening and enjoy the atmosphere and the view.

No matter what time of year, this is the place to come for the absolute best view of Bern. In addition, it's got a lovely cafe/restaurant, and an awesome playground. It's a must-see. My tip: take the bus from the station to the Rosengarten, then walk down the hill to

The Rose Garden (Rosengarten) situated on a hill, walking distance up a cobbled stone path, not far away from the Bear Park (Barenpark). It takes approx. 15 - 20 minutes of strenuous walk to reach it. Once you get there, the view from the top of Bern and the surrounding land
I walked through the rose garden today. It is a pretty place with flowers, including roses. The park also has a great view of the city. It is an easy walk from the city center and near the bears.

This is a very popular park so excellent for people watching. There were lots of rhododendrons and azaleas, sadly the roses were not in bloom yet. We had an excellent lunch in the park restaurant. The food was good and the service extremely quick and efficient, definitely a
Nice view to the city! Go at the daytime is much more attractive than at night! Three live bears were about ten minutes walking!

I stayed in an apartment close by. Walked over for a nice sunset view of Bern. It was a busy little park with lots of families having picnics and playing games and music. Not too many roses in early April.
Take some drinks and snacks witih you and go up for the great views of Rosengarten. When the weather is nice, it's packed with people who go up to meet friends and have a good time.

we went to bern in june 2016, couple, spent a day there and finished the walking tour of bern city by afternoon. it was a windy day. we went back from bear park thinking that there is nothing more to see. we even came back to railway station and some locals suggested to visit

It was nice to walk up to the rose garden and see the view of old town from the top. The garden has different types of roses. But I guess it's more beautiful to see them in the summer time when flowers are blooming.
The view of the city of Bern is one of the best you can get. The roses are flowering in summer, but the garden is nice also in spring.

Visited the rose garden on a day trip to Bern. Was quite a hard walk to get too as was very steep so may not be suitable for all. The roses hadnt blossomed because of time of year so cannot comment on those. The view was really worth it though as you could look over all of Bern

A charming walk high above the old city of Bern, with benches to sit and enjoy the view and sun, and a restaurant with panoramic windows overlooking the city. Some charming old houses on the path up to the park. Steep climb from the city though.
You can either walk up or catch the 15 bus, which stops outside. It's a relaxing place for a walk at any time of the year, with great views of the city. In the summer it is full of fabulous roses.

Great location to look out over the old city and the river below. You can walk up the hill from the bear pits to get there. The restaurant is very good. There is a lot of tourists that come and go. If you have a chance, stop and take a moment to smell the roses.

The view! All of Bern's old town can be seen from there. The place has very relaxed atmosphere and offers a great opportunity to watch the sunset over the city. I was lucky to be able to pass by every day after work and enjoy the view. A must see!
The Rose Garden offers the best views over Bern. You can walk up there from the 'Bärengraben', which is much less of a hassle than going by bus.
Beautiful gardens with wonderful overlook of Old Town Bern and the River Aare...perfect place to start your tour of the city.

The Rosengarten was until around 1875 a cemetery. It was restructured 40 years later to a public parc with more than 200 varieties of roses, and as recently as 1960 the restaurant was built on a spot with probably the nicest view over the old town of Bern and the river Aare
Today I ordered a taxi to rosengarten.. it comes after 15 minutes exactly as he promised.. came back to pick me up before time.. I feel safe with this company ..relax..comfortable..

The restaurant has a great view on Bern. Also, the inside area looks cozy, especially the terrace with a Bern view. The coffee is fine and tasty. However, the service and the behavior of waiters could be better regarding the service time and attention.
Visited during summer months so there were some flowers but overall this is small park offering beautiful views of the city and mountain !! There is small restaurant offering coffee and cake.

This is a bit of a walk but well worth it and the views of Bern and gorgeous. We visited in winter so there were no roses out but the view was just great. Nice little cafe with good coffee at the top.
The rose garden offers a beautiful view over the old part of the city of Berne. The Berneese Alps are visible if the weather is fine.

When we have company from out-of-town, we walk from the Capital, through the Old Town, past the Einstein Haus and City Hall, cross the bridge, admire the bears on the other side of the river, and finally climb up to the Rose Garden. Here, you get a wonderful view of the city
There is a great overview over berne old town and the river Aare meandering around the old city. in evenings you can watch the sun go down over the roofs.

Nice view from higher level, looking to Bern village. Night view is good as well. Enjoy a romantic meal at the restaurant there would be fantastic. Can walk down the trail to reach the Bear park then wonder along the bridge to go back to the old town Bern. A pleasurable walk to
The flowers are beautiful. Very scenic for photos. If you would like to capture a nice photo of Bern this is the place.

nice restaurant and in the Summer a nice place to relax ley n the green and smell the beautiful roses . Enjoy the view down to the old town of Bern and the River Aare if the sight is good you can see the Alpes in the Berner Oberland....

From the Rosengarden you do have the very best view over the old city of Berne and the Aare. Plus there is a nice restaurant with decent prices. If yo uare lucky and can go during rose blossom season it is stunning!

Unfortunately we came in winter time so no rose in the garden. But the view from the hill is amazing landscape of Bern with it great bridge and church tower and watch tower as well. In winter the light is special with distance fog and golden rays from the sun and hot wind from
We found nothing special. It looks just a park for morning and evening walks. Very few rose plants and not any more attractive.

Unfortunately by the time we came to visit in late November few plants were flowering however it is still possible to get a good idea of what the gardens would be like in full flower. They are well laid out and easy to walk through and there are great views over the city. A
It's a nice walk (uphill halfway) across the bridge from old town. Fantastic photo ops on the way too. Lovely place-even in October, but do it for the walk.

A definite MUST while in Bern. Short walk up the hill from the river and the live bears. You get a fantastic view of the river winding through and Bern Old Town from here. The colors in Autumn were terrific. Gardens themselves are wonderfully done being not a large area.

Very relaxing! Actually didn't see many roses in the late autumn but a great place to see Old Town Bern. Visit before noon so that you can take good photos without shadow. Then have an easy lunch on the coach enjoying the tender sunshine and falling leaves of early Nov..
Take a pic nic and enjoy the a moment sitting on the lawn or one of the many benches while enjoying the view.

It is a very nice and well maintained garden available to everyone. There is also a very nice view from the garden to the old city of Bern. Even visiting in the Autumn time is worth the effort. I can imagine, that in the right season this place is magical.
The view here is so beautiful and relaxing. You can forget all your worries just being here. haha. Although the weather wasn't really great the day we went, but the view was still really amazing.

It is not too far to walk from the stadium on Papuermühlestrasse/ Bern Expo/ the Ibis hotel and happens to be on the way to the bears. The playground as well as the whole park is great. So are the views on the river Aare and "downtown" Bern.
Went there on a rainy day but it was still nice to see Berne from the top of the hill. Really recommend the small coffee in the park.

I went at sunset. Ain't such a good idea as the sun is shinning at you. You will not be able to take a good photo. However, the view is still as stunning. Suggest going early in the morning. We walked from old town and up the slope to the place. The slope is rather steep.

The rose garden is in Bern Switzerland, it is part of a larger park where you could have a picnic. you can also walk up a little hill to view the town of Bern. When we were there the roses were out, they made a wonderful display

Nice view over the old town of Bern. 5 Minutes away from Bärengraben (up the hill). Take your pic-nic with you or have a drink at the reataurant. It's a very nice place and we spend a lot of time there playing volley with the kids, take a sunbath or just relaxing in the grass.
We were pleasantly surprised at how good the food was as we thought this restaurant was mainly known for its view. We also felt it was very reasonably priced for its quality.

The Rose Garden sits on a hill across the river from the city center with fabulous views of the bridges and the cities landmark buildings. Only 10 minutes via bus in frint of the train station. The roses are fading at this time of year but still are pretty. Also a cafe if you
These gardens offer a beautiful green space that my daughter loved running around. There's also a nice playground there. Gorgeous views of the city from here.
The rose garden is a very nice park high above the City of Bern with panoramic views and areas to sit and relax. There is a restaurant adjacent to the park if you wanted to stay and enjoy.
Rose garden is just nature everywhere but the main attraction and beauty there is the way to rose gardens. Now that is something you wouldn't want to miss.
The rose garden is a quiet and lovely place. The various roses are beautifully planted so there are separate areas to enjoy them. Also there is a wonderful view of the city.

This isn't a must-see attraction unless you absolutely love roses or have never been to a rose garden before. Nonetheless it's a pretty walk and has some magnificent views of the city in the back of the garden. I'm glad I spent about 10 minutes walking through it.
Take tram 10 and stop at the gate for this Garden. Besides roses you will enjoy a wonderful view of the Old City. There are bar and public wc

It's a bit of a hike up the hill to the Rosengarten, but you can also take a bus if you need to save some steps. Once you are there, you are treated not only to a lovely garden (especially in springtime), but also one of the best views in the city. There's also a nice
Located on a hill slightly above the city of Bern, it is hard to find a better place to go and watch a sunset in all of Bern.
The rose garden is a perfect spot for a picnic or walk. Be sure to take a gander at the overlook at Bern old town. Beautiful!

I'm from a place that has fabulous International Rose Test Gardens .. so this Rosengarten cannot compare to that. But it is a pleasant park with a few varieties of roses and a great view of the city of Bern. Quite a climb from the bear garden area but there is a place for

This is a beautiful garden to see if you are visiting. The view is breathtaking and you can enjoy this while eating or having an espresso at the restaurant. They also have a nice size playground for the kids to play in! Overall it was a great experience!
Climb to the top is quite steep but short. the view is spectacular. The garden is beautiful and has a restaurant which overlooks the city.
Great location with a wonderful view. A little trip to the ROSENGARDEN I recommend to the city visit tourist. The food is ok with this price.
The garden is a good point to overview the city and river. I enjoy the view and took a few good photos. It will be a good choice to walk down from garden to the bear park.

This Garden is very colorful in summer time when all the flowers in the garden bloom. different color of Roses and other flowers makes this a perfect place to just hang around with friends and enjoy the beautiful view of the city of Bern and Gurten. There is a restaurant too if

Beautiful flowers, great view overlooking the old town. Nice mix of tourists and locals sharing a bottle of wine or having a birthdayparty in the park. The restaurant has really great food at reasonable prices.
Lovely place with great view over the Old Town Bern. Food was delicious but quiet some... recommendation for a afternoon in the sun.

It's a short walk up to a small hill where You can see all old town. There is a garden with perfect grass and roses where you can take a nap. The view of the city are very nice. Cool place to watch the sunset.
I almost skipped this because it was uphill, but it was my favorite spot in the city. The garden is fine, but the view is wonderful and it's calm, cool place to relax and watch the city go by.

Even on an overcast and occasionally drizzly day, touring the Rosengarten was a lovely experience. There is a bus line that drops off right here, or you can hike up to it from the Aare River bank. I chose the former, and was able to get some great photos of Old Town Bern

If you`re are visiting Bern on a budget grab yourself a picnic lunch at Migro either at Bern station or on Marktgasse, you can get a good sandwich with a drink and an apple for 8.50Frs about £6.50 or 8.50$. Bern is easy to explore on foot, after leaving the city and crossing
Views are stunning - the best in Bern. Get here to watch the sun go down. Worth booking to ensure you get a nice table on the terrace. Lovely food too!
The Rose Garden is a short bus ride or a climb up a steep hill. The garden is a great place to relax, and take photos of the great vistas of the city. There is a restaurant there as well.

It is a great place to spend couple of hours walking !! There is a fantastic view offering a wonderful scenery and you are surrounded by fountains and flowers. If you have kids, they can enjoy the playgound.

Rosengarten is a great place to chill with friends, to spend an afternoon outside. It offers a beautiful scenery and you are surrounded by flowers, foutains, a playground, a restaurant. Great place.

We enjoyed an afternoon strolling through the garden, and also along the river. It was a peaceful, pleasant way to enjoy some time away from the city itself. In parts, we could see views of the alps as well.
Be sure to check out al the flowers then stand over the edge to look down on the entire section of Old Bern - best view in the city!

The views from here are great! You can come to wander around and as the Roses, but really everyone is here to get a view looking over the old town. There's also a good restaurant/bar/cafe in the garden, by the path down to the bridge. We had an outdoor table and watched the
A great way to relax and spend some time having a picnic. The day we visited there was some sort of music festival happening and was very entertaining.
Nice place for evening Hangouts with beer.nice view and kids playing place.you will love to spend time with your spouse and kids

It was one helluva climb at the end of a tiring day but the view from up there was mind blowing. Absolutely a pleasure to view.

A free bus will take you from downtown Bern to the Rose garden. Many types and colors of flowers. This is a walking park with great views of Bern. Many families and couples as well as tourists come here.

It was Swiss National Day when we visited, so we shared the sport with thousands of others - the perfect place to watch the fireworks! High on a hill overlooking Bern's old town, the rose garden provided spectacular viewing, even with the crowds. Great for sunset too. And the

It is a steep climb up to the rose garden, but worth it. This is located in old town Bern near the Bear Park. The flowers are beautiful and the view is amazing
